version.name: Aqua Boot Camp
version.description: The experience: This cardio-intensive class, led by Damien Gurganious (he and then-fiancée Nicole were contestants on the seventh season of The Biggest Loser), gives you only ten-second intervals to rest between sets, which get progressively faster. “Today is boot camp!” Gurganious reminded us throughout the hour—as if we could have forgotten, what with all the arm curling and furious jogging in place with foam weights and noodles. Both tools serve to increase resistance, though simply fighting buoyancy in the four-foot-deep pool calls for the greatest effort. How fit you need to be: Occasional exerciser.—Shayna Courtney

event.name: Abrons Arts Center at Henry Street Settlement

version.name: Abrons Arts Center at Henry Street Settlement
version.description: Classes: •Adult beginning ballet. Tue, Thu 10–11:30am. •Ballroom dance. Wed 7–8pm. Fifteen sessions $205.•Belly dance. Wed 6–7pm. Fifteen sessions $205. •Professional ballet. Tue, Thu 11:30am–1pm. •Teen/adult salsa I. Thu 6:30–7:30pm. •Teen/adult salsa II. Thu 5:30–7:30pm.

event.name: Hair: The American Tribal Love-Rock Musical

version.name: Hair: The American Tribal Love-Rock Musical
version.description: The hippies have taken over the Hirschfeld; you can be sure they’ll be squatting on West 45th for quite some time. Director Diane Paulus transfers the ecstatic, rock-driven 1968 musical from its successful revival last summer in Central Park to indoors. If anything, being inside amps up the energy and excitement. Attending Hair—still timely, still fun, still bursting with peace and love and great music—will surely lead to a contact high.—DC

version.name: Alice + Olivia
version.description: Perhaps channeling maverick Edie Sedgwick, designer Stacey Bendet’s second location is outfitted like a ’60s gem with black lacquer and retro photographs of stylish ladies. Her mod clothes follow step. Of course, plenty of Bendet’s beloved pants are on hand, along with vintage T-shirts, signature candles and her yoga line.

version.name: Chicago
version.description: This John Kander–Fred Ebb–Bob Fosse favorite—revived by director Walter Bobbie and choreographer Ann Reinking—tells the saga of chorus girl Roxie Hart, who murders her lover, avoids prison and, with the help of a huckster lawyer, becomes a vaudeville star.—DC

version.name: Alexander Technique demonstration
version.description: “You can change the habits of a lifetime in one moment,” said innovator F.M. Alexander. His mind-body movement practice is said to help with stress management, body awareness, posture and coordination. On the first Monday of every month, experts present a free introductory lecture and hands-on demonstration.

event.name: “Women Only: Folk Art by Female Hands”

version.name: “Women Only: Folk Art by Female Hands”
version.description: These samplers, quilts, rugs and other items by ladies working after the revolution reflect a national cult of domesticity. Through Sept 12.

version.name: “Approaching Abstraction”
version.description: Like many of the artists and craftspeople whose work hangs on its walls, the Folk Art Museum is finding creative uses for the materials it has at hand: Curator Brooke Davis Anderson has mounted a thrilling exhibition from the museum’s existing collection of outsider art. Through Sept 6.

version.name: “The Private Collection of Henry Darger”
version.description: The pieces this reclusive artist woke up to every morning consitute the work in this show. Through Sept 19.

version.name: “Malcah Zeldis, New York Artist”
version.description: Religion and street culture are mixed together in these urban scenes by a uniquely New York artist. Through Oct 18.

version.name: Affordable haircuts
version.description: You don’t have to shell out hundreds of dollars to get premium salon treatments. The Academy Cuts program at the Antonio Prieto Salon offers clients the option of getting coiffed by an apprentice, someone knee-deep in their training program, or a “new talent,” a stylist who is ready to take the final test to join the staff full-time, at a reduced rate.

version.name: Amateur Night at the Apollo
version.description: Amateur Night at the Apollo was launched in 1934 as a showcase for young African-American entertainers, at a time when blacks were not permitted as patrons or performers in many theaters. More than 70 years later, it’s still a hit.

version.name: Buns and Puns
version.description: Host Jonathan Powley loves baking and comedy, which is why he feeds audience members homemade buns in between his guests’ stand-up sets. The free Jell-O shots, however, probably have more to do with masochism than love.

version.name: Murdered by the Mob
version.description: The murder-mystery dinner-theater event enters its umpteenth year of comedy, Mafia intrigue and lotsa pasta. The show’s producers assure us: It’s the most fun you’ll ever have getting whacked.

version.name: Eri Yamamoto Trio
version.description: Pianist Eri Yamamoto jump-started her career in this slot, and now that her talents are being sought after far beyond the West Village, this is the place to hear all the new ideas brewing in an already compositionally agile mind. On her latest CD, Duologue (AUM Fidelity), she’s partnered with the likes of William Parker and Daniel Carter, but here she maintains her own working trio.

version.name: Recess
version.description: Every Monday, Rich Mercier and Jon Lang present a laid-back comedy show of stand-ups on the LES.

version.name: The Sherry Vine Show!
version.description: The downtown mainstay clings to her musical-comedy roots.

version.name: Become Your Best Self
version.description: In one hour, astrologer and life coach Kevin Blackwell promises to help you understand how to conquer the insecurities that block you from realizing your potential. He’ll even explore the daunting question of what your “mission in life” might be.
version.price: $150 per hour, with this listing $100 per hour

version.name: Detox Yoga
version.description:
A physically challenging series, practiced at a quick pace and repeated three or four times. Each repetition takes the series deeper into positions focused on stretching and twisting. The class was the perfect challenge for a detox—I wanted to die in the middle of it, but I was still able to follow the series. The studio draws a lot of experienced yogis, who provided good examples of proper form on more difficult positions. It was also inspiring to see them take the series to its fullest extent in complicated balance poses, headstands and other impressive configurations, which made me want to take my practice more seriously.—Noelle Stout
Level: Some experience helps.

version.name: Bikram Yoga
version.description:
Straight-up Bikram—you’ll do all the standard poses a few times each. The pace is fairly rapid, and while the teacher explains verbally what to do, she doesn’t come around and correct your form (maybe she’s a sweatphobe?). No chanting here, just lots of breathing exercises. Free-spirited yogis will dig this place’s hippie vibe, diverse crowd and liberal dress code (all shapes and sizes get half naked). But ack, it’s carpeted, and you can smell the cumulative effects of sweaty bodies on absorbent rugs. The class itself is tough; the temp gets cranked up to a challenging 104°F—and you can find just as much difficult fun elsewhere without the stench.—Corinne Mohr
Level: Some experience helps.
Schedule varies, please check website for details.

version.name: Billyburg Boot Camp
version.description: Fitness instructor Rozz Nash is stepping out of Williamsburg’s Exodus gym and into the surrounding environs to give residents a rigorous workout in local parks and other areas. Expect standard fitness routines (calisthenics and the like), along with a few unexpected body-building moves. The $377 course includes 24 classes over eight weeks. Curious? Newbies get the first class for free.

version.name: Bio
version.description: Though owner An Vu once worked in the pharmaceutical industry, you won’t find a single white lab coat at this chic Nolita boutique. Bio, short for Bio Emerging Designers, instead offers a crash course on 25 up-and-coming lines from around the world including 12th Street by Cynthia Vincent, Twinkle by Wenlan and Christopher Deane via clothing tags, which bear each designer's backstory. Catering to working ladies, Vu meticulously edits the industrial-looking joint's clothing and accessories, which includes footwear by her sister, shoe designer Taryn Rose.—Abigail Green-Dove

version.name: Holistic Fitness
version.description:
About 50 minutes of traditional vinyasa yoga, with some less traditional positions inspired by Pilates and other fitness techniques. After the mat work, the class becomes sort of like a personal training session, mixing elements of kickboxing and plyometrics. Held in a Brooklyn brownstone (the practice room features a fireplace and ornate crown molding—a beautiful focal point during relaxation), the classes are intimate, with a lot of personal attention. The surprising mix of fitness programs felt strange, but in a good way—a much needed surprise in my regular workout routine.—Noelle Stout
Level: Yoga newbies can do it.
Schedule varies, please check website for details.

version.name: BodiBalance
version.description: Class: •Gyrokinesis. Aviva Geismar: Fri 1:30–2:30pm.

version.name: Lunchtime Open Level Vinyasa
version.description:
The only chanting happened during the breathing exercises at the start and end of class (exhaling with “om”). The first few poses were held a little longer to stretch muscles. Then the poses began to flow into sequences that were repeated a couple of times each (right and left, etc.), and usually the last pose was held for a little while. There were no dogmatic speeches. Haramis explained each pose (discussing placement of feet, hands, knees and other parts) as we went through each pose/sequence the first time, and then she walked around the class to correct form. She also told funny, related anecdotes while we were holding poses, making everything very informal and encouraging. Plus, the background music was very low-key. This small, mellow class is great for clueless beginners. Initially I was worried that I wouldn’t be able to keep up, but Haramis was very clear and supportive in explaining each pose, and we were able to move at our own pace. The other students (only four of them) were more advanced, but Haramis structured the class so that everyone was challenged. It’s an awesome way to spend your lunch break, and I left the studio feeling energized.—Moira Brazier
Level: Yoga newbies can do it.

version.name: Body by Brooklyn’s Wet Lounge
version.description: Have a water-park day in the winter. The spa is offering access to this warm oasis as a recession-friendly alternative to an expensive spa day. In the past, the area was open only to those who purchased a spa treatment, but now anyone can relax in the cedar sauna, Turkish aroma steam room, traditional river-rock sauna, thermal hot tub and arctic-cold-plunge pool. The wet lounge is said to relax the nervous system, enhance circulation and promote detoxification. The only thing missing is the jumbo slide!

version.name: Chicago City Limits Improvisational Theater
version.description: Using short-form games and audience-inspired sketches, the improvisers in this old-school New York troupe create a fake debate and a Broadway-style musical at each show.

version.name: ComedySportz
version.description: This weekly event, unlike much comedic fare, is appropriate for the whole family. That means lots of warnings about clean language from the referee, who keeps two competing comic improv teams in check and invites audience participation. Ages 8 and up.

version.name: Unwrapped
version.description: The Candy Janes earn their stripes in a comedy burlesque show that involves ladies in lingerie belting rock & roll medleys and acting in silly sketches.

version.name: ComedySportz
version.description: This weekly event, unlike much comedic fare, is appropriate for the whole family. That means lots of warnings about clean language from the referee, who keeps two competing comic improv teams in check and invites audience participation.

version.name: Broadway Dance Center
version.description: Classes: •Advanced-beginner jazz funk. Chio: Wed 10–11:30am, 6–7:30pm.•All levels African. Idrissa Kelly: Sun 6–7:30pm.•Beginner tap. Germaine Salsberg: Tue 5–6:15pm, Wed 6:15–7:30pm.•Beginner theater. James Kinney: Mon, Wed 7:30–9pm.•Intermediate contemporary jazz. Slam: Tue, Thu 1:30–3pm; Sun 4:30–6pm; Wed 1:30–3pm.•Intermediate jazz. Sheila Barker: Mon, Wed, Fri 4:30–6pm.•Intermediate jazz funk. Sheryl Murakami: Mon, Wed 3–4:30pm; Saturday 6–7:30pm.

version.name: Bronx Zoo
version.price: $15, seniors $13, children 3–12 $11, children under 3 free. Wednesday pay what you wish.
version.property: More than 4,500 creatures call this urban preserve home, including snow leopards, western lowland gorillas, naked mole rats and a frisky troop of Ethiopian gelada baboons, who raise quite a din as they frolic and fight. Ongoing: “Madagascar!” The African island comes to the Bronx in this new permanent exhibit featuring five different breeds of lemurs, a pair of Nile crocodiles, geckos, a tree boa constrictor, a colony of hissing cockroaches and a variety of other indigenous creatures.

version.name: Brooklyn Botanic Garden
version.price: $8, seniors, students and children over 12 $4, children 12 and under free. Free admission all day Tuesday and Saturday until noon.
version.property: This 52-acre park is home to the climate-controlled Steinhardt Conservatory (which houses plant life from three different temperate zones), as well as gardens devoted to fragrances and plants mentioned in Shakespeare’s plays. If you want some fauna to go with your flora, check out the ducks in the picturesque Japanese Hill-and-Pond Garden. Through May 2: “Hanami” Check out spectacular blooms during the garden’s annual cherry blossom festival. The monthlong event culminates in the Sakura Matsuri festival during the first weekend of May.

version.name: “Tivoli: A Place We Call Home”
version.description: This photo exhibit documents the lives of the residents of Tivoli Towers, a high-rise, affordable-housing community in Crown Heights. The landlord is attempting to sell the building, which would force out longtime tenants (and perhaps start a wave of gentrification in the neighborhood). The portraits on view show residents who are devoted to keeping their home both a part of the Crown Heights community and as affordable as possible.

version.name: Crime & Punishment
version.description: Every week Kate Berlant welcomes a variety of stand-ups to this basement usually reserved for indie rock; lineups regularly include folks such as Sean Patton and Hannibal Buress, so you should be in good hands.

version.name: Chez Bushwick
version.description: Classes:•Body work. Stephanie Tack: Tue 4–6pm.•Hip-hop. Rebecca Marzalek-Kelly: Mon 8:30–9:30pm. •Meditation. Joseph Giacona: Sun 10am–noon. •Yoga. Diane Smith: Thu 10–11am.

version.name: Centering
version.description:
Designed for yogis of all skill levels, the moderately paced class incorporates gentle asanas and lots of breath work. You’ll feel a sense of renewal just by stepping into the small but beautiful Chopra studio. Under calming dim lighting, you’ll start your practice by concentrating on one of Chopra’s Seven Spiritual Laws of Success, which your instructor will encourage you to be mindful of throughout the session. Instructions—for poses, breathing and concentration—are clear, and attention is paid to those in need of assistance. Take advantage of the free meditation sessions 30 minutes before each class so you’re relaxed and ready to engage.—Elizabeth Barr
Level: Yoga newbies can do it.
Schedule varies, please check website for details.

version.name: Lila: Divine Play Yoga
version.description: Lila is the Sanskrit word for “amusement” and also the first name of the yoga instructor of this class, which blends dance warm-ups, physical actor training and “surprises” (think silliness)—all intended to challenge your body and mind.

version.name: Laugh It Off
version.description: Kyle Bostic hosts a diverse lineup each week.

version.name: Club Monaco
version.description: NYC retailer Club Monaco’s latest location caters to time-pressed urbanites, with free delivery service to the UWS, extended hours once a month (7am–11pm) and exclusive items such as one-of-a-kind handbags.

version.name: Too Cool for School
version.description: Both the experienced and the green get their time at Nick Turner and Jason Saenz’s bi-weekly stand-up showcase.

version.name: Covet Jewellery
version.description: Given its minimalist decor—a handful of orchids and dark-wood vitrines—this subterranean West Village shop might seem bare at first glance. But inside lurks L.A.-bred designer Alexa Garner Sidaris’s diamond-studded works. Her first NYC outpost offers carat-encrusted but not overly ornate stunners and ocean-inflected specimens such as shell earrings and abalone pendants.

version.name: Go Pogo class
version.description: Remember running around recess as a kid and never realizing you were exercising? Revert back to childhood with this new circuit-style fitness class that uses the Fly Bar—a modern day pogo stick—to provide a great cardio workout. What are you waiting for? Hop to it!

version.name: A Dolphin Up a Tree
version.description: Young theatergoers who attend this adaptation of Kimberly Foster’s award-winning picture book do more than just watch. At the end, they help rescue the main character when her magic spells transform her into a dolphin and her stuffed animals into live critters. The songs, composed by John Fleming, emphasize the importance of cooperation and acceptance of others for who they are. Even kids who aren’t fans of musicals are apt to find the costumes (and set) hilarious. Ages 2 to 8.

version.name: Zero Hour
version.description: By all accounts, the great Zero Mostel (Fiddler on the Roof) blazed most brightly in live performance. So we owe writer-performer Jim Brochu a debt of gratitude for this extraordinary act of reincarnation (directed astutely by Piper Laurie), which restores the outsize actor to us in all of his daunting dimensions. From the moment that Brochu spins around to face the audience, he is a Hirschfeld drawing come to pulsing life. You can’t help being swept up in the tornado of energy.—AF

version.name: Vinyasa Open
version.description:
The well-paced class flows fluidly from one pose to the next. Owner Julia Frodahl’s instruction is gentle and encouraging—which distracts from the fact that her class is rigorous and challenging: You will break a sweat before moving into forward bends and inversions, then you’ll cool down and sink into a most welcome final savasana. The studio is an intimate loft space a few blocks from the Lorimer St–Metropolitan Ave stop of the L train, ideal for a mindful practice: The lighting is warm and dim, music is low-key and eclectic. Frodahl is an attentive instructor, making subtle adjustments that bring more precision to each individual’s practice—rotating the upper arms while in downward dog, pulling fingertips to stretch a tad farther before moving into triangle. Bonus: At the beginning of class, Frodahl asks for pose requests, and tailors the session to accommodate.—Amanda Meffert
Level: Some experience helps.

version.name: Seth Rudetsky’s Broadway Chatterbox
version.description: Proceeds from Rudetsky’s tell-all dishfest benefit Broadway Cares/Equity Fights AIDS.

version.name: Our Way, Your Way, Broadway
version.description: The Don’t Tell Mama staff struts its stuff at this weekly open-mike show-tune night.

version.name: Recession-proof your hair
version.description: Just because your funds are limited, it doesn’t mean you have to start trimming your own locks. Donsuki Salon is offering unlimited free trims when you purchase one haircut ($75–$150) during the economic crisis.

version.name: Brian Newman After Dark
version.description: Jazz noodles as burlesque dancers try not to whip their pasties into your veal at this naughty supper club event.

version.name: The Sweets’ Shop
version.description: Melody Sweets and the Candy Shop Boys hurry to give you a sugar rush with a decadent revue.

version.name: The Earegulars
version.description: The Earegulars usually include local singer-guitarist Matt Munisteri and cornetist Jon Kellso, but the two have been on the road sporadically as of late. Even if they don’t show, you can expect a well-honed crew for this regular Sunday night jam.

version.name: East Village Walking Tour
version.description: Dutch colonialists, struggling immigrants, Victorian fops, guitar-toting hippies, skate punks, yuppies—the East Village has embraced ’em all. Discover the history of this ever-changing community on Eric Ferrara’s tour through one of the world’s most famous hamlets.

version.name: Empire State Building
version.price: $20; seniors, children 12-17 $18; children 6-11 $14; children 5 and under free. Tickets to the 102nd-floor observatory cost an additional $15.

version.name: Energy Fitness membership
version.description: You’ll be greeted by name when you walk into this small, friendly gym owned and run by a personal trainer with a martial arts background. Commitmentphobes will like the no-strings-attached monthly membership ($65, groups of five friends or more $50 each), and combat nuts will love the month of unlimited martial arts classes ($100).

version.name: Whipped!
version.description: At each of the five timed circuit stations, you’ll rotate between a full-body and a core exercise, using a variety of tools including jump ropes, kettlebells and 30-pound strength ropes Each station’s workout is easily adaptable for any ability level, plus it’s you versus the clock, working at your own pace. So even though I wasn’t bustin’ the same moves as the guy in the Coast Guard T-shirt, I still felt challenged, a lot of it thanks to the encouraging guidance of the wildly enthusiastic instructor, Marie. Would you expect anything less from a class with an exclamation point in the title? How fit you need to be: Occasional exerciser —Beth Furtwangler

version.name: Parkour Power Play
version.description: The experience: This indoor class is incredibly fun. Jumping over vaults, Spider-Man crawling across the floor and leaping from plastic-step plank to plastic-step plank makes you feel like a kid on the playground (except for the jolts and pains in your definitely adult body). And to their credit, the super-advanced trainers from the World Freerunning and Parkour Federation—including Michael from MTV’s Ultimate Parkour Challenge—were able to break down every spring, hop and bound-over into clearly understandable steps. As with any new course, the kinks are still being worked out: Some of the equipment was simply too high or too far apart for us short folks to navigate. So while still fun, the game just seemed unfair. How fit you need to be: Gym regular.—Billie Cohen

version.name: Overcoming Fear, Anxiety and Worry
version.description: This weekly class, led by Western Buddhist nun Kelsang Demo, focuses on the root causes of fear, how it manifests itself and how to overcome it.

version.name: Laughs at Luca Lounge
version.description: Giulia Rozzi, Heidi Edsall and Selena Coppock welcome stand-ups, storytellers and musical guests to this new biweekly variety show.

version.name: Lucky Lotus’s yoga and meditation
version.description: Yoga benefits the mind, body and soul, and at Lucky Lotus, it doesn’t take a toll on your wallet either. Take advantage of a reduced-price yoga class on a Tuesday evening and stick around for the free meditation session that follows—all for the approximate cost of two lattes.

version.name: Yoga Bail Out
version.description: The economically stressed can breathe a sigh of relief at this affordable yoga class, designed to help you through these difficult times. The class will teach you postures that are said to elevate your mood, eliminate toxins, soothe lower-back pain, stimulate digestion and build strength. Putting $10 toward improving your body is probably a safer investment than the stock market these days.

version.name: Zumba at Ludlow Fitness
version.description: In a class of 20 women, I was happy to learn I wasn’t the only student without a background in dance. In fact, the instructor might have been the only one who knew what she was doing; the rest of us followed along as best we could to the basic steps, set to Latin, reggae and Bollywood rhythms. There were very few verbal cues; we mostly attempted to keep on beat and emulate what we saw at the front of the classroom. Overall, this was a low-stress, easy workout, not much different than going to a dance club—though easier in sneakers than it would have been in heels. How fit you need to be: Couch potatoes welcome —Francesca Soroka

version.name: The Addams Family
version.description: Inspired by Charles Addams’s macabre cartoons, this musical features pleasant, clever songs (by Andrew Lippa), sly jokes (by book writers Marshall Brickman and Rick Elice) and swoony visuals—yet the whole never soars to the heights we expect of a bona fide hit. But although the production could be edgier and more grotesque, it’s not the crass theme-park disaster that some say it is. Nathan Lane, Bebe Neuwirth and a generally strong ensemble land their jokes and numbers with aplomb.—David Cote

version.name: The Phantom of the Opera
version.description: Andrew Lloyd Webber’s bombastic musical of Gaston Leroux’s 1911 novel is set in 19th-century Paris. Directed by Harold Prince, the beautifully produced Phantom is lavish and engaging enough to draw tourists 22 years into its run.—DC

version.name: Manhattan Movement & Arts Center
version.description: Classes: •Advanced jazz. Matthew Neff: Sat 5–6:30pm.•African. Vado Diomande: Fri 7:30–9pm.•Intermediate ballet. David Howard: Sat 10:30am–noon. •Intermediate jazz. Lindsay Chambers: Tue, Thu 1–2:30pm.•Intermediate theater dance. Diego Funes: Wed 1–2:30pm. •LindaFit Pilates. Aimee Covo: Wed, Fri 6:30–7:30pm.

version.name: Evolve
version.description: The experience: A quick-paced series of jumping jacks, lunges and strength-training moves pack the first 30 minutes of this intense session. To keep momentum high, and also play off the large class size, instructor Gonzalo Garcia divided the group into small teams for the quaintly coined “suicides.” We raced from one end of the room to the other, squatted to touch a base, then scrambled to find a spot on the floor for various sets of crunches. Even the end-of-class mat stretches were a workout. It’s an invigorating start to a Saturday; be prepared to feel that resistance-band arm work in the days that follow. How fit you need to be: Gym regular.—Shayna Courtney

version.name: Mark Morris Dance Center
version.description: Classes: •Advanced-beginner Pilates. Blossom Leilani-Crawford: Wed 6–7pm.•Beginning ballet. Angie Ng: Thu 7–8:30pm.•Beginning modern. Chelsea Glassman: Wed 7–8:30pm.•Intermediate-advanced belly dancing. Arianna Al Tiye: Mon 7–8:30pm.•Intermediate West African. Kouyate Ismael: Wed 7:30–9pm.•Open level Afro-Caribbean dance and movement. Pat Hall: Sat 3–5pm.•Open Pilates. Ashley James: Mon 7:30–8:30pm.•Open yoga. Mia Borgatta: Mon 6–7:30pm.

version.name: Contemporary Belly Dancing
version.description: The experience: This class was an interesting combination of very low-key calisthenics and highly mechanical, memorization-based steps and hip swivels. The adept, reliably spirited instructor catered to all levels, meaning that the girl who moved to the music in her own head, the in-the-know regulars with their jangling bangles and me, directionless yet energetic, all had to follow the same routine. It was an hour well spent, though I would have preferred to have wiggled more and memorized less. How fit you need to be: Occasional exerciser. —Rebecca Katherine Hirsch

version.name: Gossip Girl Sites Tour
version.description: Spotted: Gossip Girl fanatics touring the sites made famous on the CW’s teen soap opera, including Henri Bendel, the Palace Hotel and Blair Waldorf’s palatial Fifth Avenue building. The three-hour-long bus tour hits more than 30 locations that have been featured on the show. OMFG!

version.name: Metrostar Talent Challenge
version.description: Who wants to be a cabaret star? (We mean it: Who?) Find out as aspiring singers compete for a fully produced run at the Met Room next year in the second annual edition of this American Idol–style competition, judged by a panel of experts and voted on by the audience.

version.name: Annie Ross
version.description: The septuagenarian Annie Ross remains as hard-swinging, glamorous and funny as when she was one third of the legendary jazz-vocal trio Lambert, Hendricks and Ross. See her and you’ll understand what jazz used to be: an expression of the danger, the fun and the high-wire life between the notes.

event.name: “ Intertwined: Contemporary Baskets from the Sara and David Lieberman Collection”

version.name: “ Intertwined: Contemporary Baskets from the Sara and David Lieberman Collection”
version.description: This assemblage of fiber sculptures and baskets represents both traditional and nontraditional techniques. Through Sept 12.

version.name: White’s Lies
version.description: A divorce lawyer and committed bachelor invents a family in Ben Andron’s new comedy, whose fancy cast includes Tuc Watkins, Peter Scolari, Christy Carlson Romano and the always compelling Betty Buckley. Bob Cline directs.

version.name: Naked Boys Singing!
version.description: Eight reasonably nice-looking men take it all off and vocalize in this hour-long collage of cutesy vignettes on gay themes. But the titillation of their flashing wears off in a flash. Although sex is central to most of the numbers, the goofy nudism has no erotic charge; and when the show tries to be serious, it is hard to watch with a straight face.—AF

version.name: Gazillion Bubble Show
version.description: Family soapmasters Ana, Fan and Jano Yang give bubbles a better rap with their massive soap-and-air creations, paired with lasers and other light effects.

version.name: Avenue Q
version.description: After six years—that includes a Broadway run and then a return to its Off Broadway roots—the sassy and clever puppet musical doesn’t show its age. The current cast is perfectly capable and likable, and Robert Lopez and Jeff Marx’s deft Sesame Street–esque novelty tunes about porn and racism still earn their laughs. Avenue Q remains a sly and winning piece of metamusical tomfoolery.—David Cote

version.name: The 39 Steps
version.description: An innocent man evades killer spies, the police and a diabolical German professor in this spoofy, four-actor stage version of the 1935 Alfred Hitchcock noir thriller. And escape is what this amusing diversion (newly transferred from Broadway) has to offer: chuckleworthy theatrical silliness that, while never hilarious, is thoroughly clever.—DC

version.name: ImaginOcean
version.description: The puckish John Tartaglia (Avenue Q) takes kids on an undersea adventure in this one-hour family musical. Special effects, such as an black-light ocean floor, should appeal to young sea urchins.

version.name: New York Aquarium
version.property: Check out eerie moon jellyfish, fierce sharks and adorable black-footed penguins. Be sure to say hi to Squirt, the aquarium’s giant Pacific octopus. Ongoing: Sea lion show Four-year-old Duke is the scenery-chewing diva of the aquarium’s pinniped spectacular (daily 11:30am, 3pm).

version.name: “Policing a Changed City”
version.description: This tribute to New York’s Finest highlights the NYPD’s efforts to fight crime and terrorism using new technology and community outreach.

version.name: “9/11 Remembered”
version.description: Filmed interviews, photographs and artifacts from Ground Zero are all on display in this chronicle of the NYPD’s role in responding to the September 11 attacks.

version.name: Sunday Night Live
version.description: Jamie Roberts hosts a mix of rising club comics and stand-ups who’ve already broken through to the cable-TV-spot level.

version.name: Uncensored Comedy
version.description: Dustin Chafin hosts stand-ups in a no-holds-barred environment. Audience members are warned in advance that the talent has a green light to tell the sort of jokes that might typically be banned. Guests such as Dave Attell and Mike DeStefano regularly stop by.

version.name: The Clayton Fletcher Show
version.description: Actor-comedian Fletcher hosts this weekly show with a top-notch lineup.

version.name: NY Running Club Running Classes
version.description: The experience: Yep, it’s running. But don’t regard this as a pay-for-play casual jogging group. Each person sets his or her own pace, but if coaches spot (a) talent or (b) laziness, they’ll push you to step it up. The goal isn’t just to get moving, but to get better—and maybe even inspire you to sign up for that next big race. If you’re not wiped out by the time you return to the school to collect your stuff, see (b). How fit you need to be: Any level; you choose your goal based on your ability. Beginners aim for 20 minutes of jogging without stopping; intermediates are casual runners who want to improve; and advanced runners are competitive racers.—Amy Roberts
version.price: Ten-week, ten-class course $125, members $105; ten-week, 20-class course $250, members $180

version.name: Catwalk Confidence
version.description: The experience: Though this class is designed to eliminate the pain associated with wearing stilettos, unlike other “high-heel fitness” exercises, there’s no prancing around in your Manolos or competing in Zoolander-style walk-offs. This is a serious barefoot workout that combines moves from yoga (downward dog, child’s pose), Pilates (plank, swimming) and ballet (pliés, arabesques), to build stability from the ground up. Catwalk Confidence creator and instructor Dr. Emily Splichal (she’s a podiatrist) emphasizes movements that develop good posture and that strengthen ankle, foot and knee muscles. But this isn’t just a lower-leg workout—I felt the burn most in my stomach and glutes the next day. How fit you need to be: Occasional exerciser.—Cristina Velocci

event.name: The Henry Luce III Center for the Study of American Culture

version.name: The Henry Luce III Center for the Study of American Culture
version.description: An astounding archive of historical items—including a plaster model used in the creation of the Lincoln Memorial, an authentic 18th-century coach and Victorian businessman Charles Larned Robinson’s sizable collection of apple parers—is exhibited in the society’s fourth-floor repository.

version.name: Forrest Yoga (open) with Erica Mather
version.description:
This class usually begins with guided breathing, some type of neck opener and a series of challenging abdominal exercises, followed by sun salutations, inversions and/or sequences based on a particular skill (e.g., back bends, hip openers, chaturangas). The session incorporates props (blocks, blankets, a rolled-up mat, belts), and the instructor offers individual adjustments. Forrest Yoga, named after its founder, Ana Forrest, uses intense pose sequences and mindful breathing to “bring aliveness to every cell of your body.” It emphasizes abdominal work (core strength), keeping the neck relaxed and the feet and hands engaged, along with a few other key principles that distinguish it from other yoga practices. TOm Factory, designed by architect and director Faramarz, is true to its name—the space itself inspires peacefulness. Mather manages to teach physical and spiritual intelligence through yoga without being dogmatic or hokey, and has developed a loyal following in NYC. While the pace of this class is moderate, it is a high-intensity workout. You’ll hold the poses for a longer amount of time than in a vinyasa class, and you’ll deepen your poses as the class progresses. Mather offers students the option to increase or decrease the level of difficulty of particular positions, and circulates to adjust students’ postures.—Shayna D. Skarf
Level: Some experience helps, though beginners are welcome.

version.name: Yoga fight club
version.description: The aggro-yogi is a rare species: He hates child’s pose, refuses to wear cropped yoga pants and chants out of tune. With this rebel (and all others who are a little sick of “om shanti” classes) in mind, OM Yoga has created a new class that combines yoga, cardiovascular training, strength conditioning and the age-old human instinct to fight. Using boxing gloves, mitts and kick pads, students can safely explore different fight techniques while moving through full body conditioning and vinyasa yoga circuits.

version.name: Michael Powers Frequency
version.description: Singer-guitarist Michael Powers behaves like he has a Delta hellhound on his trail. We’re not so sure that’s the case, but the gritty soul on his record Prodigal Son is befitting a cat who apprenticed with James Cotton.

version.name: Steve Maglio: Sounds of Sinatra
version.description: Maglio performs a sound-alike tribute to the Chairman of the Board, backed by the Stan Rubin Orchestra.

version.name: Permanent Collection
version.description: Permanent collection.

version.name: Vinyasa
version.description:
The class started with simple stretches and breathing, and the poses became more challenging as we warmed into it. Co-owner Anne-Margaret Redding-Wood moved through the room correcting form as needed and encouraging everyone through the more difficult moments. The studio has a real neighborhoody, community feel to it, and this class completely reflected that. For one thing, the class began with Redding-Wood reciting an inspirational quote, and then having us introduce ourselves and share something that we’re really good at. She shared that she’s a good motivator, and she wasn’t wrong. Each student was given individual advice and encouragement, which would normally make me want to slink my anxious, wobbly beginner form right out the back entrance, but everyone was so friendly and Redding-Wood’s adjustments were so helpful that I welcomed the attention. The exercises varied from relaxing stretches to strenuous pose-holding, and alternatives were given for the more difficult moves if they were beyond our skill level. I left the class exhausted but somehow refreshed, and more than a little proud of myself for (sort of) nailing that headstand. Afterward, I even treated myself to the studio’s massage services, and I’m not kidding when I say it’s the best massage I’ve ever had. It was full-body deep-tissue, and co-owner and head massage therapist Anthony Wood totally personalized it to deal with my recent cold, working specifically on my lung triggers.—Carly Guarino
Level: Yoga newbies can do it.

version.name: Vinyasa Basics
version.description:
The class begins and ends with the teacher reading a passage about “doing no harm” to others or yourself, and yeah, there’s some de rigueur chanting. We moved fairly quickly through poses, holding certain difficult ones for a few extra breaths. This class is for people who are new to yoga, or who have not been practicing regularly and want a refresher. We moved through vinyasa sequences slowly and methodically, the instructor’s soothing voice successfully tuning me out of workday thoughts and focusing me on my breathing. Over the course of the 90 minutes, each of the eight students got personal attention, and we all ventured to try more challenging poses (like crow and headstand) toward the end.—Jessica Rohls
Level: Yoga newbies can do it.
Schedule varies, please check website for details.

version.name: Tom Ford
version.description: Perhaps with the goal of bringing sexy back to a corner of the UES best known for preppy polo shirts and pleated khakis, the former Gucci creative director—infamous for his male-cleavage-baring outfits—won’t disappoint fans with his first eponymous boutique. Outfitted like a posh bachelor pad with beaver rugs, a bar and fireplaces, the bi-level space exhibits his classic menswear, created in collaboration with Italian fashion house Ermenegildo Zegna. If an off-the-rack, four-digit suit isn’t posh enough for you, head up the ebony staircase or velvet-lined elevator to the made-to-measure floor, where three private dressing rooms cosset clients in need of custom tennis shorts.

version.name: The Awesome 80s Prom
version.description: In this interactive dance party, actors playing the stereotypical class of 1989 at Wanaget High wander around and improvise as the crowd shakes its booty. The show works fine as a girls’ night out, but as theater it’s, like, totally bogus.—Adam Feldman

version.name: Anusara
version.description:
Class starts and ends with meditation in restorative poses (read: nap time, with yoga props arranged under and around your body to hold you in a yogic shape). In between, the teacher drags you through some slow-down dogs and standing poses. My inexperienced teacher was best at guiding us through relaxation, helping me slow my breath and calm my body. But she lacked confidence in the asana department: She often suggested Sanskrit pose names with no English equivalent, no clear “right foot forward, arms up” instruction and no demo. “When you’re ready, no pressure,” she cooed, as if our hesitancy came from reluctance rather than confusion. It was hard to let go and trust a teacher who seemed afraid to make too strong a suggestion of any sort. But I’d try another class in this cozy, plant-filled space, which I shared with just two other students on a recent visit.—Megan Gendell
Level: Some experience helps.
Schedule varies, please check website for details.

version.name: YLLI
version.description: Former Bergdorf’s fashion coordinator Fetije Madzuric is partial to her neighborhood, Williamsburg, so she didn’t venture too far from home to open her first boutique. The shop—whose name is pronounced “illy,” and it’s the Albanian word for “star,” is housed in a 5,000-square-foot loft, with brick walls that are lined with pieces from indie and well-known labels alike. Among the goods are Thea Grant’s antique gold epaulet earrings, men’s striped henley shirts from Orange County label Fremont and Converse by John Varvatos skull-and-crossbones tees.

version.name: Zoë
version.description: Intimate NYC boutiques are to corner delis as Zoë is to a full-fledged supermarket. This Dumbo outpost for high-end garb, located in a cavernous former box factory, organizes a dizzying array of designers—among them Miu Miu, Zac Posen and Pucci—in its cement-floored space. Highlights at the satellite store (its flagship is in Princeton, NJ) include a Mayle sweaterdress , a cocktail number by 3.1 Phillip Lim and more than 18 denim lines. It’s a shame there aren’t discount coupons for this megamart.

event.name: Pianobar Mondays with Susan Campanaro and Eric Garcia

version.name: Pianobar Mondays with Susan Campanaro and Eric Garcia
version.description: The East Village’s cozy Boxcar Lounge gives itself over to the Great American Songbook in a friendly open-mike evening hosted by Susan Campanaro.

version.name: Rock of Ages
version.description: Even if you never grew a mullet or banged your head at a Quiet Riot concert, this insanely fun mixtape musical will hit your retro sweet spot. A parade of pop and metal ballads fits beautifully with Chris d’Arienzo’s self-mocking book. It’s Urinetown for the I Love the 80s crowd. Kristin Hanggi’s frisky staging bursts with visual gags. Rock of Ages shatters irony with a killer drum solo, then melts the wreckage with a smoking guitar riff.—DC

event.name: Tour the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine

version.name: Tour the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine
version.description: Hallelujah! Take a tour of the world’s largest Gothic cathedral and see the results of a five-year-long refurbishment project that restored the North Transept, including every inch of limestone, marble and granite, at this New York City landmark.

version.name: Beginner/Basic Yoga
version.description:
As the name implies, this class is for those just starting out: The flow is slow, yet challenging enough to engage someone at an intermediate level. The space and overall vibe was laid-back and very comfortable: The lights were dimmed, the room was aromatic and cozy, and the nonjudgmental students faced each other on two rows of mats. As we moved through poses, instructor Ramit Kreitner stressed the importance of breath and ultimately, the necessity of giving one’s self over to the practice entirely in order to obtain clarity. I don’t know how much clarity I found, but the workout was definitely more relaxing than strenuous. And at the end, Kreitner dabbed our ankles with warm scented oil while we reclined in the final pose.—Angela Sundstrom
Level: Yoga newbies welcome
version.price: Single class $15, first class $10, packages available

version.name: President Jackson
version.description: In between sets by more-established comics, up-and-comers get to do five minutes and compete for a cash prize. Joe Dixon and Calvin Cato host.

version.name: Red
version.description: John Logan’s bioplay about AbEx icon Mark Rothko falls into the usual trap of leaden research and hagiography. The playwright dares to be grandiloquent, pompous and wildly pretentious—qualities he passes on to Rothko (Alfred Molina), depicted as a bullying boor desperate to burnish his legend before suicidal impulses overwhelm him. Molina is lusty and engaging, but Eddie Redmayne’s assistant is a thin, obvious foil (the actor’s American accent and affect are rather phony). It’s saying something when the piece’s best moments are when these two just shut up and paint.—DC

event.name: Martha Graham School of Contemporary Dance

version.name: Martha Graham School of Contemporary Dance
version.description: Classes (Graham technique): •Advanced (levels III–IV): Mon–Fri 10:35am–12:05pm. Elementary (level I): Mon–Fri 9–10:30am. •Intermediate (level II): Mon–Fri 12:10–1:40pm.

version.name: Hatha Yoga Open
version.description:
Geared more toward gymgoers than traditional yogis, this class moves quickly and focuses on flowing from one pose to another. Since it’s an open class, the teacher offers modifications for more advanced students, as well as suggestions for toning and stretching. A class that caters to students of all ages and multiple skill levels can be boring, but this rendition managed to stay interesting. The instructor kept the pace moving and encouraged advanced practitioners to make modifications, so that everyone had a shot at inducing sore muscles. Nonetheless, experienced yogis may find the class a little too soft: The teacher discouraged us from attempting headstands because the studio’s floors are hardwood.—Amanda Meffert
Level: Some experience helps.
Schedule varies, please check website for details.

version.name: Michael Aram
version.description: Magpies beware: You’ll take a shine to the cache of glittering home goods at this metalware designer’s eponymous emporium. Located in a restored 19th-century carriage house, the all-black space makes stars of Indian-inspired pieces such as polished aluminum trays and vases)—both of which bear natural touches such as imprints of actual leaves and bark. Inside his blackened-aluminum signature Sona bowls lies a 24-karat gold interior—a miniature version of the store itself.

version.name: Cobra Clutch
version.description: Josh Guarino asks everybody to walk under the BQE for an evening of stand-up the first Friday of every month.

version.name: National Comedy Theatre
version.description: With shows similar to Whose Line Is It Anyway?, National Comedy Theatre keeps short-form improv alive in Hell’s Kitchen.

event.name: New York City National Comedy Theatre Show

version.name: New York City National Comedy Theatre Show
version.description: Two teams of professional comics compete against each other based solely on audience suggestions. Don’t worry, the content’s clean—we asked. Ages 10 and up.

event.name: Serenity Spa’s Honey and Milk Manicure and Pedicure

version.name: Serenity Spa’s Honey and Milk Manicure and Pedicure
version.description: As it turns out, the biblical substances are good for manis ($35) and pedis ($60), too: Honey protects and rejuvenates, and milk is full of protein and moisturizing properties. Get both your hands and feet done at a discount—for $75—and leave feeling heavenly.

version.name: Yoga for Vets
version.description: As a small thank-you for the life-threatening services war veterans have provided, the New York Sports Clubs in Glendale will offer them weekly complimentary yoga classes to help reduce stress. The gratis sessions are a complement to the programs provided by the Queens Vet Center, a counseling service that helps veterans of all wars readjust to civilian life.

version.name: “Haunted: Contemporary Photography/Video/Performance”
version.description: The work in this show, while widely varied, all embodies the idea of being tied to the past in some way. Through Sept 6.

event.name: The Goldfish Twins Swim the Big Blue Sea!

version.name: The Goldfish Twins Swim the Big Blue Sea!
version.description: Denise Devin and Christopher Reiner’s family-friendly musical comedy follows two goldfish lost in the ocean, where magical eels and singing turtles try to help the fish-out-of-the-right-kind-of-water get back home. The show also performs on Sundays at 10:30am and noon at the Actors Temple Theatre (339 W 47th St between Eighth and Ninth Aves).

event.name: Danny and Sylvia: The Danny Kaye Musical

version.name: Danny and Sylvia: The Danny Kaye Musical
version.description: Robert McElwane, who was Danny Kaye’s publicist for decades, crafts the libretto for this affectionate look at the lovable musical-comedy star and his wife, Sylvia Fine. Brian Childers and Kimberly Faye Greenberg play the central couple; Pamela Hall directs.

version.name: My Big Gay Italian Wedding
version.description: Gay celebrity Reichen Lehmkuhl is one of the grooms in this revival of Anthony J. Wilkinson’s 2003 comedy about same-sex nuptials, directed by Teresa A. Cicala.

version.name: Monster Sundays
version.description: DJ Tony Cruz spins a tea dance at this legendary Village watering hole, where the vibe is old-school friendly.

version.name: CTMD Tantshoyz
version.description: Social dancing:•Yiddish dance party and workshop. First Thursday of each month 7–10pm. Beginners are welcome.

version.name: Underdog East
version.description: This loungey East Village men's shop houses a winning cache of classic dudes' threads with up-to-date twists. Proprietor Douglas Michael fills the shop with such modern lines as Filippa K, Steven Alan and t-shirt label Red Toe Nails—all of which are sartorial home runs.

version.name: South Pacific
version.description: Bartlett Sher’s revival of Rodgers and Hammerstein’s 1949 World War II musical is faultlessly decorous. The staging is elegant; the cast acts with restraint and sings beautifully; the 30-piece orchestra swells with pride. Although some elements of the plot seem a bit corny, the score is a treasure, and the audience swoons. Laura Osnes plays the love-struck Nellie Forbush, and Paulo Szot is her soigné suitor.—AF

version.name: 92nd Street Y Harkness Dance Center
version.description: Social dancing: •Israeli folk dance. Wed 7pm–12:45am. $12. •Spring Ballroom Fling: Sat 24 8pm–midnight. $15, advance $13.

version.name: Pilates Mat / Ballet Barre
version.description: The experience: Led by a professional ballerina, the Y’s fusion course takes participants through a gradually intensifying workout. Light stretches transition into core-strengthening Pilates exercises like arm pumps and roll-ups. Then come the ballet barre steps: pliés (squats) and tondues (leg extensions) to name a few. The result is satisfying—you work your core (abdominals, back and pelvis) and limbs to increase body alignment, flexibility and strength. And while you’ll leave feeling energized, you won’t feel overworked. How fit you need to be: Occasional exerciser.—Sandra Plasse

version.name: A/X Armani Exchange
version.description: You'll still find plenty of “greige,” Italian designer Giorgio Armani's signature neutral hue at his more-affordable line's outpost, but its trendier, street-influenced styles draw a younger crowd than his high-end label's Madison Avenue boutique. Denim is, of course, de rigueur here, along with party-friendly gear sure to be a hit among the club-hopping set.

version.name: A/X Armani Exchange
version.description: You'll still find plenty of “greige,” Italian designer Giorgio Armani's signature neutral hue at his more-affordable line's outpost, but its trendier, street-influenced styles draw a younger crowd than his high-end label's Madison Avenue boutique. Denim is, of course, de rigueur here, along with party-friendly gear sure to be a hit among the club-hopping set.

version.name: Acupuncture happy hour
version.description: Ditch your coworkers the first Thursday of each month and get your happy-hour fix at Acupuncture for Athletes. Instead of downing three beers, nab a half-hour needle-poking session, which aims to leave you feeling rejuvenated and relaxed. Just don’t demonstrate the technique on your buddies with darts next week.

version.name: Complimentary aikido lesson
version.description: If you want to smack down a potential predator without actually harming him or her (ethical self-defense, if you will), then check out aikido, a Japanese martial art. Unlike wrestling, it teaches coordination, and as this new studio puts it, “vehicles for the cultivation of life, knowledge, virtue and good sense, not devices to throw and pin people with.”

version.name: “Cosmic Collisions”
version.description: Take a stunning journey through deep space to witness the creation of the moon, the violent meeting of two stars and the collision of the Milky Way with the Andromeda spiral galaxy in this Hayden Planetarium show narrated by Robert Redford.

version.name: Mysteries of the Great Lakes
version.description: Fun fact: The North American Great Lakes have the largest concentration of fresh water in the entire world. Which would be a great thing, if the lakes themselves weren’t “on the brink of ecological catastrophe” (according to a Congressional bill that proposes different ways to restore the lakes to good condition). This film examines the gigantic bodies of water, looking at the creatures that live in and around the five lakes, and what can be done to preserve them.

event.name: “Highway of an Empire: The Great Inca Road”

version.name: “Highway of an Empire: The Great Inca Road”
version.description: Talk about a superhighway: It’s estimated that the Great Inca Road covered more than 20,000 miles in South America. The photos in this exhibit showcase the various constructions currently used to traverse the roadway (including suspension bridges and paved paths).

version.name: “Lizards and Snakes: Alive!”
version.description: The titular animals of this exhibit belong to an order of reptiles called squamates—meaning “scaled.” This exhibit, which returns to the museum after several successful previous runs, features more than 60 reptiles from five different continents.

version.name: “SonicVision”
version.description: The museum teamed with MTV2 and pop maestro Moby (he mixed the soundtrack featuring Radiohead, Goldfrapp, Coldplay and U2) to produce this computer-animated dreamscape, beamed onto the interior of the planetarium’s dome ($15).

version.name: The Discovery Room
version.description: This interactive area for kids features hands-on exhibits about everything from anthropology to astrophysics.

event.name: Anne and Bernard Spitzer Hall of Human Origins

version.name: Anne and Bernard Spitzer Hall of Human Origins
version.description: Using both fossil records and DNA evidence, this updated permanent exhibit traces the connections between modern man and our earliest ancestors (and a few distant relations) and features rare hominid fossils and artifacts, engaging video segments and realistic dioramas. There’s also a hands-on classroom where children can literally get a grip on our ancient progenitors.

version.name: “Journey to the Stars”
version.description: Get an up-close and personal view of the stars in our universe in the museum’s newest space show, narrated by Whoopi Goldberg. The film shows the creation of new stars billions of years ago, and explores the lives of these celestial bodies (including their deaths—one part simulates the eventual destruction of the Sun).

version.name: Spider-Silk Textile
version.description: The museum presents this miniexhibit of a large piece of textile, woven out of the silks of more than 1 million spiders from Madagascar. Arachnophobes may want to steer clear.

version.name: “Spectacular Stibnite”
version.description: The museum’s rare half-ton mineral specimen—the largest stibnite on public display—features hundreds of glittering, swordlike crystals jutting from a rocky base.

event.name: The Rose Center for Earth and Space

version.name: The Rose Center for Earth and Space
version.description: The museum’s space-age wing includes the renovated Hayden Planetarium and several innovative exhibits about the evolution and history of the universe.

version.name: Arthur Ross Hall of Meteorites
version.description: This exhibit explores our 4.5-billion-year-old solar system through interactive displays and specimens, including the 34-ton Ahnighito meteorite, discovered by Admiral Peary during an 1894 arctic expedition.

version.name: Basic Yoga
version.description:
The session begins with sun salutations and moves through what’s essentially Yoga 101 (downward-facing dog, cobra and the like) at a brisk pace. Though it’s billed as a basic class, I found this to be quite challenging. Much of the practice focuses on basic positions, which are held for several breaths at a time—making them all the more difficult. (You can do downward-facing dog only so many times before your wrists start to hurt like hell.) The instructor, Tina, offered modifications for some of the poses, and the experience was ultimately beneficial; but I’m not sure that the muscle soreness, which left me unable to raise my arms the next day, was worth it. True beginners may want to stay away.—Amy Plitt
Level: Some experience helps.

version.name: Blue Man Group
version.description: Three deadpan, blue-skinned aliens work their way (with comical puzzlement) through the trappings of modern culture in this crowd-pleasing East Village happening. For sheer, weird, exuberant fun, it’s hard to top this long-running treat, which may be the world’s most accessible piece of multimedia performance art.—Adam Feldman

version.name: Jersey Boys
version.description: The Broadway musical does right by the jukebox with this behind-the-music tale, presenting the Four Seasons’ energetic 1960s tunes (including “Walk Like a Man” and “Big Girls Don’t Cry”) as they were intended to be performed.—AF

version.name: Our Town
version.description: Director David Cromer and two dozen actors revivify Thornton Wilder’s American classic by meeting this frighteningly profound play head-on, without sentimentality or the false balm of nostalgia. A tartly ironic Stage Manager (Michael Shannon) guides us through 12 years in small-town New Hampshire; along the way, Wilder pulls focus way back to reveal a cosmic dimension. This is a muscular reckoning with a great work, totally contemporary yet true to the original.—DC

version.name: Bittersweets New York
version.description: Maggots, earthworms and serpent tongues aren’t exactly what most ladies would use to complement their décolletage. At this offbeat jewelry-and-beauty boutique, however, these creepy-crawlies serve as inspiration for the gilded accessories from co-owner Robin Adams. She began designing baubles five years ago, after working on a silver compass for the third installment of artist Matthew Barney’s Cremaster film cycle. Now, those of us tired of cliché charms can pluck up these decidedly ungirly pieces.

version.name: Escandalo Night
version.description: Head north to hang with the hot men and women of way uptown.

version.name: Empire Dance classes
version.description: Spare yourself from workout monotony with a number of different introductory classes at this studio, including hatha yoga, belly dancing and a striptease workout. Show this listing and try a sample class for $5.

version.name: Fela!
version.description: Working with a fierce dancing corps and the commanding Sahr Ngaujah in the title role, choreographer-director Bill T. Jones has orchestrated a soul-scorching mash-up of pounding African dance, political protest and intoxicating Afrobeat (the jazz-funk-drum style Fela Kuti pioneered). The resulting piece is more than the sum of its overlapping genres: dance party, musical bioplay, agitprop rally and concert. Jones creates something more than a musical; Fela! is an ecstatic phenomenon.—DC

version.name: Magical Nights
version.description: Before this showcase of the self-described “classiest magicians” gets started (starting at 5:30pm), the rotating cast of prestidigitators will perform their sleight of hand close-up at your table. They retreat to the stage for a formal show at 7pm.

event.name: Discount acne treatment for college students

version.name: Discount acne treatment for college students
version.description: If you’re plagued by pesky pimples (and you can’t stand to watch another Proactiv commercial) try GKAY professional skin care. Current college students (just show a valid student ID) can get one step closer to a clear face with GKAY’s acne facial for $85 (normally $115).

version.name: Wicked
version.description: This musical prequel to The Wizard of Oz addresses surprisingly complex themes, such as standards of beauty, morality and, believe it or not, opposition to fascism. Thanks to Winnie Holzman’s witty book and Stephen Schwartz’s robust, pop-inflected score, Wicked soars. Currently, the cast features Mandy Gonzalez as Elphaba and Katie Rose Clarke as goody-two-shoes Glinda.—DC

version.name: Ginette_NY Jewelry Bar
version.description: Following a brief stint studying art history at the Sorbonne and decorating French homes, Provence native Frédérique Dessemond found her current calling when she moved to Brooklyn. Her first Manhattan location is dedicated to her chic line, based on the traditional adornments worn by women in her hometown of Marseille. Discover pieces that marry flat disk shapes with personalized details such as custom initials, words or numbers.

version.name: Brooklyn Idol
version.description: Sing your heart out with other undiscovered talents at the Slope’s most fun lesbian karaoke night.

version.name: Basics with Joelle Hann
version.description:
A brisk yet beginner-friendly session, capped off with a Maya Angelou poem and a group om. Joelle Hann used the dimmable lighting and music to good effect, controlling the mood of the room. She also watches over her students with a sharp eye, supplying blocks and straps and correcting alignment. You’ll sweat during the more active part of the class, but you’ll leave feeling limber and relaxed, rather than fatigued.—Jonathan Shannon
Level: Yoga newbies can do it.

version.name: Kudalini Gong
version.description:
Each class is a kriya, a series of movements and repetitions—which are never the same twice. Chanting, singing, New Age music and breathing exercises are included. Even the kundalini people warn you that kundalini is one of the weirder yogas. Good news for the self-conscious, though: The whole thing is done with eyes closed—so we could look inward (or not be embarrassed). The movements themselves seemed strange—during a long chair pose we whipped our heads from side to side and chanted. But our instructor explained the meanings behind our movements, so no matter how bizarre it was, we never felt uncomfortable or left out. Our payoff was an extra-long savasana at the end, during which the instructor played a gong and some droning music and we got pretty close to feeling blissful.—Emily Jacobson
Level: Yoga newbies can do it.
Schedule varies, please check website for details.

version.name: Joe McGinty’s Piano Parlour
version.description: Joe McGinty used to helm Keyboard Karaoke at the Lucky Cat in Brooklyn every Monday night. Now, he plays with friends at Googie’s and, perhaps, knocks out some karaoke.

event.name: Joe McGinty’s Piano Parlour with Scrote

version.name: Joe McGinty’s Piano Parlour with Scrote
version.description: Joe McGinty used to helm Keyboard Karaoke at the Lucky Cat in Brooklyn every Monday night. Now, he plays with friends at Googie’s and, perhaps, knocks out some karaoke.

version.name: Drip
version.description: Lee Chappell’s fabulous affair (on the first floor of this trendy hotel) is like two bashes rolled into one: a playful gay pool party and a colorful cocktail-lounge soiree, hosted by an assortment of drag queens and freaky nightlifers. Music’s by DJ Scotty Rox.

version.name: (Area) Code
version.description: The Shelter’s Timmy Regisford and other NYC club heroes supply the late-night sounds at 150 Varick St (the former home of Shelter), where you’ll be dancing to soulful house and classics well into Sunday. E-mail areacodenyc@gmail.com for more info.

version.name: “Images & Artifacts from the Recovery”
version.description: Proceeds from this permanent exhibit—featuring official Ground Zero photographer Gary Marlon Suson’s poignant images—benefit several 9/11 charities. Reservations are required.

version.name: HH Design: Shop
version.description: A reason to ride the G train, local handbag label Hayden-Harnett’s first boutique brings Soho-esque style to a far-flung corner of Greenpoint. Inside its mod digs, slouchy leather satchels fill almost every nook, with the exception of the line’s spanking-new retroish womenswear and vintage Yves Saint Laurent sunglasses.

version.name: Intensati
version.description: . The experience: I was a little skeptical of a class that involved shouting things—while working out, no less: This series of aerobics, yoga, martial arts and dance moves correspond with spoken affirmations (“Believe! Receive!”). But I dropped all inhibition about 20 minutes in, and found myself confidently punching the air, chanting, “I be-lieve I will suc-ceed!” while dripping in sweat. Multitaskers of New York, rejoice, because this class is not only exhilarating cardio, it also serves as therapy. Turns out, yelling “Courage! Confidence!” while doing martial arts actually makes you feel (dare I say it?) empowered. Sound a little cheesy? Maybe it is. But I walked out a sweaty mess, so if nothing else, it’s a high-energy workout. How fit you need to be: Occasional exerciser.—Beth Furtwangler

version.name: Next Fall
version.description: Geoffrey Nauffts’s romantic comedy-drama, about an atheist and his Christian boyfriend, rises to Broadway without losing the lovely intimacy of Sheryl Kaller’s direction and high-quality ensemble actors. None of the latter are matinee names; the production feels like a leap of faith. The best new American play of the Broadway season, Next Fall leaves you thinking about rapture and rupture. If you go, which you should, be prepared to laugh some, perhaps to cry some, and then to rise in appreciation.—AF

version.name: Halloween: Young Frankenstein
version.description: Directed by Susan Stroman (The Producers), the overhyped show pokes fun at movies based on Mary Shelley’s Frankenstein. The story follows the mad scientist’s grandson as he resumes a family tradition of exhuming the dead. Ages 10 and up.

version.name: Level I Iyengar
version.description:
Methodically practicing poses, with lots of beneficial pauses to watch the instructor demonstrate. Our Level I class was in a rental studio that is also home to trapeze and capoeira classes, giving the space a creative, DIY feel. All the yoga sessions are taught by Lara Brunn, who comes off as knowledgeable and entirely trustworthy. Our poses developed from basic stretching to more involved movements. And there were a number of props available—bricks, folding chairs and ropes attached to one wall (which, unfortunately, are reserved for higher levels of practice). With Brunn’s good instruction, and encouragement, we were all doing impressive shoulder stands halfway though the class. I came feeling tangled and left smoothed and limber.—Emily Jacobson
Level: Yoga newbies can do it.
Schedule varies, please check website for details.

version.name: Sage Stand-Up
version.description: This long-running show changed its name slightly when the Sage Theater closed and its venue changed; Harrison Greenbaum and Sam Morril still host rising stars and headliners alike.

version.name: Billy Elliot
version.description: Stephen Daldry has brought his Tony Award–winning musical, with songs by Elton John, to New York.

version.name: Billy Elliot
version.description: This soul-stirring London import is based on the beloved 2000 movie about an English mining-town boy who dreams of being a ballet dancer. The material overflows with heart, grit and spectacular dancing—qualities that make Billy Elliot one of the most passionate and exhilarating shows to land on Broadway in years. Stephen Daldry’s superb direction pulls together dance, working-class drama and domestic tear-jerking into an electrifying whole.—DC

event.name: Terese Genecco and Her Little Big Band

version.name: Terese Genecco and Her Little Big Band
version.description: The marvelous Terese Genecco—who ranked among TONY’s top ten cabaret acts in 2006 and 2007—hits Iridium, goosed by a cooking midsize band. Genecco’s snappy, zippy swing leaves you feeling happily woven into an inner circle of frisky retro fun.

version.name: Tony Scherr
version.description: You probably know Tony Scherr best for his work as a bassist in Sex Mob and one of Bill Frisell’s trios. He’s also an estimable singer-songwriter, and his second solo disc, Twist in the Wind, shows it.

version.name: Jane Eadie
version.description: For this U.K. native, traveling around the world did much more than rack up some major frequent-flyer miles as an assistant to the Prince of Wales and the president of Polo Ralph Lauren; it inspired her to open a quaint Nolita jewelry boutique. The tiny, shabby-chic nook is like the United Nations of adornments, bringing together Italian designer Daniela de Marchi’s cocktail rings and JMR Fontan’s cuffs from Brazil, among other hard-to-find pieces from around the planet.

version.name: Yoga Basics
version.description:
As a beginners’ class, no poses were too difficult, and the instructor, Diana Rilov, worked within everyone’s abilities. The class warmed up with simple stretches, before moving into wall stances. This was an excellent introduction to both the basic poses and the deeper stuff, like using the wall to position myself at a 90-degree angle with my feet in the air (not as easy as it sounds, thanks to a tight lower back, but I was amazed at what I was able to do with Rilov’s calming support). Because every pose was adjusted to accommodate my limited flexibility, I could put myself in even the most challenging positions. Instead of spiritual instruction, Rilov chattily made reference to everything from The Shawshank Redemption to eating Twizzlers.—Adam Fulrath
Level: Yoga newbies welcome
Schedule varies, please check website for details.

version.name: Jamin Puech
version.description: While the rest of us are downsizing, this Paris-based label is trading in an old tiny space for a new one with 1,400 square feet. The store may have kept its zip code, but this newly designed depot now offers more than just girly trinkets. While handbags still reign supreme (don’t be blinded by the special-effect lighting that illuminates these precious bags), Puech has commissioned two Parisian interior designers to curate antiques that serve as decoration and are also available for purchase. Brave the spotlight for a green flapper-style beaded evening purse ($1,135) and for day-goers, a silver leather purse bedazzled with stone-and-metal bullets ($530).

version.name: Kundalini Yoga Sunday Evening
version.description:
Chanting is followed by 45 minutes of not-strenuous yoga, 15 minutes of relaxation and 15 minutes of mediation. This intimate class (on the day I went there were only three of us) in a Park Slope brownstone is not for the spiritually uncomfortable. While the focus is on upper-back and shoulder tension, we spent a lot of time on our breath: huffing and puffing in various rhythms, while holding traditional yoga poses. After 45 minutes of stretches, we endured 11 minutes of chanting “God and me, me and God are one” over and over in a traditional Hindu pose. The session concluded with rest and a delicious cup of tea, no praying necessary.—Caroline Voagen Nelson
Level: Yoga newbies can do it.
Schedule varies, please check website for details.

version.name: Hearing screenings
version.description: While most New Yorkers drown out the never-ending noise of the city, you can’t ignore the harm the constant clamor might cause. Everything from blasting iPods to trucks honking can cause hearing loss. The Center for Hearing and Communication offers free screenings every Tuesday and Thursday at its state-of-the-art audiology center.

version.name: Yoga Quickies for Midtowners
version.description: Even the most harried New Yorkers have time for a quickie. Raise your spirits with an hour-long yoga class during lunch, happy hour or late at night. All levels welcome; you might even learn some new positions—er, poses.

version.name: Tell Your Friends
version.description: Liam McEneaney’s “workout comedy room” offers comics a place to try new material.

version.name: Looped
version.description: Valerie Harper has a gay old time playing Tallulah Bankhead in what is otherwise a fusty old-time gay play. One of the past century’s great stage divas, Bankhead rolled in the scandal sheets offstage, and her boozy, sexy, wisecracking antics eventually turned her into a self-parodic camp icon. It’s a hellion of a part, but playwright Matthew Lombardo forces her into a lumbering plot and distorts a key incident from her career for the show’s focal point. This abuse of dramatic license is a cheap shot in depicting a woman whose lifelong license was dramatic enough.—AF

version.name: Merce Cunningham Studio
version.description: Cunningham technique: •Intermediate: Mon, Wed, Fri 10–11:30am; Tue, Thu 4:30–6pm; Sat 11:30am–1pm. •Open elementary level: Mon–Fri 6–7:30pm; Tue, Thu, Sat 10–11:30am; Sun 11:30am–1pm. Faculty includes Robert Swinston, Carol Teitelbaum, and current and former members of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company.

event.name: Mercy Corps Action Center to End World Hunger

version.name: Mercy Corps Action Center to End World Hunger
version.description: This giant Ed Schlossberg–designed space is loaded with hands-on exhibits (like a map that provides info on poverty and malnutrition at the touch of a finger) and videos (narrated by Tina Fey!)—basically the kinda 101 stuff it takes to make people care about this unforgivable global epidemic.

version.name: SRSLY LOL
version.description: Three self-proclaimed “twisted fags”—H. Alan Scott, Garry Hannon and Bryan Wilson—host Metro’s bimonthly comedy hour, which should loosen everybody up before Queer-a-oke.

version.name: “Epic India: Scenes from the Ramayana”
version.description: This grouping of Indian miniatures tells the story of the divine king Rama. Through Sept 27.

event.name: “Sounding the Pacific: Musical Instruments of Oceania”

version.name: “Sounding the Pacific: Musical Instruments of Oceania”
version.description: The incredible cultural diversity of the Pacific Islands has given rise to a great variety of musical instruments; come see a selection of them in this exhibition. Through Sept 6.

event.name: “Mary and Michael Jaharis Galleries for Byzantine Art and the Medieval Europe Gallery”

version.name: “Mary and Michael Jaharis Galleries for Byzantine Art and the Medieval Europe Gallery”
version.description: Look for the new Medieval Europe gallery and the museum’s recent acquisition—a rare Byzantine manuscript—in the renovated and reorganized space. Ongoing.

version.name: New Greek and Roman Galleries
version.description: After more than five years of construction, this “museum within a museum” (displaying an impressive collection of Hellenistic, Etruscan, Southern Italian and Roman artworks) is open to the public, concluding a 15-year redesign of the Met’s outstanding collection of classical art. Ongoing.

event.name: “Vienna Circa 1780: An Imperial Silver Service Rediscovered”

version.name: “Vienna Circa 1780: An Imperial Silver Service Rediscovered”
version.description: One can only imagine the dinners that took place using these table services, which include tureens, candelabras and cutlery, among many other items. Through Nov 7.

event.name: “Doug + Mike Starn on the Roof: Big Bambú”

version.name: “Doug + Mike Starn on the Roof: Big Bambú”
version.description: A cresting wave greets visitors to the Met’s famous rooftop terrace. Through Oct 31.

version.name: “Tracking the Credit Crisis”
version.description: Who really knows what’s going on with the current economic crisis? If you’re as confused as we are, this exhibit—which features an enormous timeline outlining the key moments of this financial nosedive, including bank failures, the collapse of the housing market and the implementation of President Obama’s stimulus package—may help.

version.name: “Performance 7: Mirage by Joan Jonas”
version.description: This installation is the evolution of an ongoing performance piece the artist made in response to a trip to India in the ’70s. Through May 31.

version.name: “Picasso: Themes and Variations”
version.description: This expansive show focuses on one of Picasso’s most generative mediums—that of printmaking. Approximately 100 examples of his work throughout decades of development are on view. Through Sept 6.

event.name: “The Modern Myth: From Francisco de Goya to Matthew Barney”

version.name: “The Modern Myth: From Francisco de Goya to Matthew Barney”
version.description: Myth as narrative-propagating metaphors is the focus of this show. Through Sept 6.

event.name: “Rising Currents: Projects for New York’s Waterfront”

version.name: “Rising Currents: Projects for New York’s Waterfront”
version.description: A P.S.1 architecture residency resulted in some creative methods for dealing with encroaching sea levels. Through Oct 11.

version.name: “Action! Design Over Time”
version.description: This show of dynamic design highlights the potential for static objects to have kinetic visual punch. Ongoing.

event.name: “Lee Bontecou: All Freedom in Every Sense”

version.name: “Lee Bontecou: All Freedom in Every Sense”
version.description: This small installation of sculptures and drawings shows Bontecou’s work in an intimate setting. Through Aug 30.

version.name: “Rocket Park”
version.description: Check out replicas of two historic NASA rockets—the 110-foot Titan/Gemini and the 102-foot Atlas/Mercury—in the museum’s outdoor playground.

version.name: “The Sports Challenge”
