version.description: Learn about balance, friction, aerodynamics and other scientific principles in this hands-on exhibit. Visitors can shimmy up a rock-climbing wall, clock the speed of their pitches and perfect their jump shots.

version.name: “Show Me the Money”
version.description: Featuring one of the system’s last “money trains,” this exhibit traces the fate of the more than $6 million collected daily as it goes from the fare box to the bank.

version.name: The Laughing Stock
version.description: Kenny Tilton hosts this weekly show featuring a couple of seasoned vets and any number of newbie stand-ups dipping their toes in the comedy pool.

version.name: West Side Story
version.description: Arthur Laurents presides over this revival of the 1957 musical about rival gangs and star-crossed lovers. Set to music by Leonard Bernstein, with lyrics by Stephen Sondheim, the production features Jerome Robbins’s choreography (as reproduced by Joey McKneely).
version.property: Subway: A, C, E to 42nd St–Port Authority; N, Q, R, W, 42nd St S, 1, 2, 3, 7 to 42nd St–Times Sq.

version.name: West Side Story
version.description: Book writer and director Arthur Laurents pilots his infamous gang members, the Jets, out of lovable-ruffian territory in a revival of this 1957 classic. Karen Olivo’s Anita offers a potent mix of sexual bravado and streetwise sadness, and Josefina Scaglione embodies Maria with heart-lifting simplicity. But the chief glories remain Leonard Bernstein’s score and Jerome Robbins’s truculent-balletic choreography. This subtly recalibrated revival is Broadway in fine form: standing up to face darkness head on and unafraid to be a thing of beauty.—AF

version.name: The Comic Book Club
version.description: Comic-book nerds, take heed: Every week, local comedians talk shop with industry professionals from all corners of the comic-book world in this hybrid show.

version.name: Bring It!
version.description: Jay Welch hosts this weekly comedy open mike. Tellers of the best joke of the night win a drink on Welch immediately following the show.

version.name: SuperFree Wednesday
version.description: A free comedy show in four parts: At 7, 8, 9 and 10pm, catch six house improv teams; at 11pm, hop on stage for the amateur jam.

version.name: Harvard Sailing Team
version.description: The recent NYU grads in Harvard Sailing Team perform new, quality sketches of the stylized, choreographed and rehearsed variety.

version.name: Cardiolates
version.description:
What to expect: The workout begins with, as you’d expect, core work—but then moves on to mini trampolines for the heart-pumping portion.
Cardiolates is a Pilates-infused workout created by identical twins and former Rockettes Kimberly and Katherine Corp. The idea here is that you can get your fat-burning-cardio fix, in addition to the conditioning and alignment benefits that Pilates offers. If you’re like me, you’ll also get a good dose of the giggles: The cardio part takes place on mini trampolines, which make the class—populated by a handful of youthful women and led by the fabulous Ron, who at moments was definitely channeling Richard Simmons—feel more like a slumber party than an exercise routine. After several initial minutes of focused core work (it really burns!), we mounted our trampolines and set to work putting our sports bras through the toughest crash test since the invention of the pogo stick. At first, it was easy (see above: giggles and slumber parties). About 20 minutes in, the nonstop jumping paired with hand-weight tricks and repetitive leg kicks started taking its toll. While I never reached heart-pounding exhaustion, 35 minutes of bouncing, plus that initial abs routine, made this a full-body workout. One that I’ll regret tomorrow, no doubt.—Kate Lowenstein
How in shape you need to be: Occasional exerciser

version.name: Project Wednesdays
version.description: DJ Ricardo Moderno reigns over this weekly night, featuring $2 shot specials and (because no Hell’s Kitchen dive would be complete without ’em) free hot dogs.

version.name: Postnatal Yoga
version.description:
After each student tells the others her name, the age of her baby (welcome in class, as long as he or she is not yet mobile), what part of the body she’d like to focus on that day and if she has any injuries, everyone is eased into the workout with the aforementioned oms, some gentle stretches and a chest-opening posture. Then it’s onto the vinyasa portion, during which you move through poses pretty quickly; expect lots of warriors, lunges, hip-opening pigeon poses, abs-building plank poses and pelvic-floor-restoring Kegel exercises—plus breaks for moms who need to nurse their squawking infants. Instructor (and studio director and certified doula) Deb Flashenberg watches with a keen eye, and is constantly roving the room to make adjustments. She may have a background in musical theater, but her vibe is never annoyingly perky—just sweet, funny and wonderfully supportive (“Those poses look gorgeous!”) to the new moms who flock here. Easy-to-follow sequences focus on bringing postpregnancy muscles back to life, and on opening chests and relaxing necks that seize up from nursing and carrying babies. The class is restorative and invigorating, and rewards you with satisfyingly sore muscles the day after. It’s a treat to be in a room of women who understand both your physical fatigue and your jiggly-belly frustration—as well as with an instructor who is determined to boost your strength and confidence.—Beth Greenfield
Level: Yoga newbies can do it.

version.name: Tai chi
version.description: The uninitiated may only know tai chi from walking by people practicing it in Central Park. If they caught more than just your eye, take an introductory lesson in this ancient meditative art at the Ramakrishnananda Center. The first two classes are free.
version.price: First two classes free, four-class card $55

version.name: Pilates on Call
version.description: Does the thought of actually getting off your couch deter you from going to the gym? Whether you’re agoraphobic or just immensely lazy, Pilates expert Alycea Ungaro wants to help you stay fit without having to leave the comfort of your own home. The Pilates on Call program from Real Pilates studio doesn’t require a gym membership; an instructor shows up at your apartment with all the tools you need: an exercise mat, a Pilates magic circle to intensify your workout and the signature Portable Plates chart to help you continue your workout after the trainers are gone. If you can tear yourself away from Shear Genius, that is.

version.name: $25 Pilates workout
version.description: Any type of exercise is beneficial, but according to Alycea Ungaro, owner of Real Pilates studio, mat classes can only get you so far. If you want to up the ante on your workout (without increasing the cost) take advantage of Ungaro’s 45-minute equipment-based class, where unlike on a mat, you can practice hundreds of different exercises.

version.name: In the Heights
version.description: This bouncy barrio musical has plenty of old-fashioned Broadway heart, and a thrilling beat: composer’s Lin-Manuel Miranda’s invigorating pulse of Latin rhythms, mixed with the percussive dynamism of hip-hop. But the show’s energy has deflated since its 2008 debut, and new cast members bring out the worst in Quiara Alegría Hudes’s contrived, sentimental book.—AF

version.name: Happy Hour Performance Salon
version.description: Bronwyn Rucker and Barbara Mundy host this weekly open mike for singers, poets and comedians, with Jerry Scott at the piano.

version.name: Penny’s Open Mike
version.description: Spoken-word artists, musicians and other creative folks are invited to put their two cents in at this weekly gathering hosted by Penny Pollak.

version.name: Perfect Balance
version.description: Class: •Perfect Balance (featuring slow, concentrated exercises). Cindy Aikman: Tue, Thu 12:30–1:30pm.

version.name: Suck My Diskoteque
version.description: DJ Steven Paul spins dance, pop and hip-hop to warm you up for the late-night bash, hosted by Southern belle Bianca Del Rio.

version.name: The Waldorf-Astoria
version.description: Get a behind-the-scenes tour of one of the city’s most luxurious and historic hotels, and enjoy lunch at Oscar’s, where eggs Benedict and the Waldorf salad were popularized. Registration is required.

version.name: A Little Night Music
version.description: First the bad news about Trevor Nunn’s revival of the 1973 Hugh Wheeler–Stephen Sondheim classic: The eight-piece band sounds puny, the sets are drab, and some actors mug their way through the show. On the plus side, Catherine Zeta-Jones is charismatic as flinty stage diva Desirée, of “Send in the Clowns” fame, and as her world-weary mother, Angela Lansbury is disarming and delightful. But Nunn seems to prize Sondheim’s lyrics way above his music; the songs are sung lugubriously. Worth seeing but still disappointing, this chamber reduction seems pixelated in a Broadway house.—DC

version.name: A/X Armani Exchange
version.description: You'll still find plenty of “greige,” Italian designer Giorgio Armani's signature neutral hue at his more-affordable line's outpost, but its trendier, street-influenced styles draw a younger crowd than his high-end label's Madison Avenue boutique. Denim is, of course, de rigueur here, along with party-friendly gear sure to be a hit among the club-hopping set.

version.name: Urban rebounding at Asphalt Green
version.description: A solid hour of trampolining proved euphoric, energy-depleting and breast-painful. Our substitute instructor, Sharon, was a fireball of bouncy, determined energy, and she led her pupils firmly and encouragingly. I admit that I couldn’t always follow the (simple) footwork (I am mechanically inept). However, in the moments I stopped trying to mimic Sharon’s moves and just let the hyperactive Top 40 remixes accompany my ceaseless, clumsy jumping, it was kind of like vertigo, and kind of like ecstasy. How in shape you need to be: Gym regular—Rebecca Katherine Hirsch

version.name: Level I Yoga
version.description: Following a collective om, the class of roughly 20 people moved from pose to pose with ease. Instructions were delivered quickly, leaving less experienced students flailing behind the rows of elastic-bodied experts. After each movement, the instructor pranced around, adjusting hips, shoulders and toes to assure that each person was aligned correctly. I felt like an outsider breaking into a forbidden cult: What started with simple middle-school-gym-class stretching session soon turned into a barrage of foreign commands that meant nothing to me. Ultimately, I was able to cobble together some poses based on what others around me were doing. And though it was shameful standing near a 50-year-old man with better flexibility and stamina than I have, I did enjoy breaking free of my rounded shoulders and stiff neck, for a few fleeting moments.—Anna Brand

version.name: Cirque du Soleil: Banana Shpeel
version.description: Cirque du Soleil leaves its usual grand acrobatic pageantry behind to risk going in a completely new direction: a comedic circus show, conceived and directed by clown king David Shiner. After a troubled run in Chicago and extensive delays for reworking, the show is finally ready for audiences. Will the Cirque’s bananas have appeal? We are curious yellow.

version.name: Beauty Bar Comedy
version.description: Vince Averill and Jesse Popp host stand-up comedy from comics you know and others that they think you should.

version.name: Betsey Johnson
version.description: In step with this exuberant, cartwheeling designer, who once employed Edie Sedgwick as her shop's model, the superfemme party dresses at this boutique exude a hip, retro vibe. Leopard-print everything, lacey lingerie and '50s-style pin-up glamour attract savvy teens looking for prom outfits and grown-up lasses seeking adorable, young-at-heart pieces.

version.name: Betsey Johnson
version.description: In step with this exuberant, cartwheeling designer, who once employed Edie Sedgwick as her shop's model, the superfemme party dresses at this boutique exude a hip, retro vibe. Leopard-print everything, lacey lingerie and '50s-style pin-up glamour attract savvy teens looking for prom outfits and grown-up lasses seeking adorable, young-at-heart pieces.

version.name: Betsey Johnson
version.description: In step with this exuberant, cartwheeling designer, who once employed Edie Sedgwick as her shop's model, the superfemme party dresses at this boutique exude a hip, retro vibe. Leopard-print everything, lacey lingerie and '50s-style pin-up glamour attract savvy teens looking for prom outfits and grown-up lasses seeking adorable, young-at-heart pieces.

version.name: Better Life Acupuncture sessions
version.description: Janine Ptaszek specializes in musculoskeletal pain and stress-related problems, including anxiety and depression. A 90-minute introductory acupuncture session is $120, and subsequent 60-minute treatments are $80. Receive a free personalized essential-oil mixture when you mention this listing. Call for an appointment.

version.name: Next to Normal
version.description: As Diana in this surprising and moving musical about a mentally ill suburban housewife, Alice Ripley has a voice like steel wool: It’s tough and cloudy at once, and it scrubs to the core. There is nothing glamorous or campy about this unlikely musical-theater heroine, and Ripley is riveting. Brian Yorkey and Tom Kitt’s songs merge show-tune influences with more radio-ready styles. Next to Normal is the rarest of Broadway species: a thoughtful, emotional musical for grown-ups.—AF

version.name: Brooklyn Bridge Boot Camp
version.description: Take in some of the best views of the New York skyline while sculpting your butt during this one-hour class that travels across the one-mile-long Brooklyn Bridge. Define your abs, slenderize your hips and thighs, tone your arms and get your heart in top shape with a high-energy crowd. Founder Ariane Hundt says you can burn up to 800 calories per hour during “New York’s toughest new workout.”

version.name: Build-a-Bear Workshop
version.description: At this St. Louis–based retailer's Fifth Avenue flagship, stuffed animals can be personalized from the get-go—long before they're “customized” with a slobber-covered ear or a missing eye. Here, kids and indulgent parents alike can choose a bear, a dog, a cat or even a flamingo and bring it to life by filling it with fluff from a spinning, glass-sided stuffing machine. Two floors of clothes and accessories allow you to deck out your new friend out in a Hawaiian hula costume with a coconut bra or Yankees uniform. Aspiring animal costumers can even design a T-shirt that's made while you wait.

version.name: RightRides: Free Car Service
version.vendor-category: Gay & Lesbian | It's Here, It's Queer
version.description: This women-run nonprofit wants you to get home safely—they invite women and trans people to call for a free ride (in parts of Brooklyn and downtown Manhattan) in a Zipcar.

version.name: Big Terrific
version.description: New-breed darlings of the alt scene Max Silvestri, Gabe Liedman and Jenny Slate typically draw big names to their warm show in Williamsburg.

version.name: Dim Sum Burlesque!
version.description: Calamity Chang hosts a roster of variously gendered performers (including torch singer Broadway Brassy) for this rotating revue of hot dishes.

version.name: Ballet Arts
version.description: Classes: •Advanced-beginner ballet. Carol Sumner: Tue 7–8:30pm, Sat 2:30–4pm. Diana Cartier: Sat 11:30am–1pm.•Advanced-intermediate ballet. Kenny Larson: Mon, Wed, Thu 7–8:30pm; Wed, Fri 10am–noon; Tue, Thu 3:30–5:30pm; Sat 5:30–7pm. Ludmila Raianova: Tue, Thu 11:30am–1pm. Jack Hertzog: Fri 7–8:30pm. Kirill Matveev: Mon, Wed, Fri, Sat 1–2:30pm; Tue, Thu 2–3:30pm. Natalya Stavro: Mon, Fri 4–5:30pm. Lonné Moretton: Sun 12:30–2:30pm. Diana Cartier: Mon, Tue, Thu 10–11:30am. •Ballet workout. Ji-Young Sim: Sat 10:30–11:30am.•Basic beginner ballet. Cornel Crabtree: Mon 11:30am–1pm. Dawn Hillen: Wed 4–5:30pm, Fri 2:30–4pm. Carol Sumner: Fri 5:30–7pm, Sun 2:30–4pm.•Contemporary. Nina Buisson: Mon, Thu 5:30–7pm. •Essential stretch. Nina Buisson: Wed 2:30–3:45pm, Fri noon–1pm. •Floor Barre (Rommett Technique). Lonné Moretton: Sun 11am–12:30pm.•Hip-hop/house. Kumi Tsuji: Tue 8:30–10pm.•Pointe. Ludmila Raianova: Tue, Thu 1–2pm. Carol Sumner: Sat 4–5pm.•Theater dance. Stephen Reed: Tue, Wed 5:30–7pm. Yumiko Niimi: Mon 2:30–4pm.•Voice. Bettina Sheppard: Thu 12:30–2:30pm. Misa Ogasawara: Tue 3–5pm.•Yoga. Paul Keoni Chun: Wed noon–1pm. Antonia: Thu 9–10am.

version.name: Created by You
version.description: Dissatisfied with the shoddy crap your kids brought home from their public school art class? Bring them to Created by You in Staten Island, where they can learn how to do arts and crafts properly. Classes are offered in a wide range of disciplines, including pottery, painting and assembling stuffed animals.

version.name: Tony n’ Tina’s Wedding
version.description: The kitschy, pushy mother of all interactive dinner theater continues its unstoppable run. Tourists may get a kick out of this tacky slice of outer-borough life, but others will balk at the high price, skimpy plot and prison-grade cuisine. Unless you have an urgent need to dance to “YMCA” with strangers, you can safely send your regrets.—AF

version.name: Russian Kettlebells
version.description: The experience: While kettlebells are newly trendy, Fighthouse’s take on them is decidedly old-school: Expect the heavy cast-iron variety, not the candy-colored plastic ones you’ll spot at certain health clubs. Instructor Steve Strickman walks newbies through safety protocols (No. 1: don’t hit anyone with your kettlebell) and carefully demonstrates every exercise. Each rep is done either for endurance and conditioning—say, one minute of swinging the kettlebell through your legs during squats—or for strength, as with six reps of one-handed overhead presses. The easy stretching between and after reps is much appreciated—as is a hot shower the next morning. How fit you need to be: Gym regular. e-mail stricker1@sprynet.com to reserve a spot.—Amy Roberts

version.name: Fille de Joie
version.description: Modeled after a turn-of-the-20th-century bedroom, Parisian boutique Fille de Joie stocks vintage picks such as floral Versace blazers and purple Maud Frizon suede ankle boots.

version.name: “Politics in Pottery”
version.description: This exhibit honoring Napoléon III’s 200th birthday features a selection of Victorian Staffordshire portrait figures from the collection of Christopher Forbes.

version.name: Giorgio Armani
version.description: Milan meets Madison Avenue at this illustrious Italian designer's temple of understated chic. The four-floor boutique—decked out like a manse with dark wood floors and marble walls—provides both genders all the elegant accoutrements they'll need for opening night galas and power lunches.

version.name: Punk Rope
version.description: Re-create recess at warp speed: Tim Haft’s playful punk rock–fueled workout combines jump-roping, unusual conditioning drills, and games aimed at increasing your endurance, agility and coordination, and decrease your waistline. No jump-roping experience necessary; ropes are provided.

version.name: LMAO
version.description: The show’s acronym tells us to laugh our asses off, but this topical—and pricey—musical sketch and variety show (ring-led by David Green) must still hope to get some of those departing butts into seats.

version.name: Hip Nosis
version.description: Las Vegas hypnotist Justin Tranz entrances and exits in an evening of family-friendly mesmerism.

version.name: “In Defense of New York”
version.description: Trace the evolution of our city’s coastal defense through 18th- and 19th-century weaponry and uniforms.

version.name: “Battle of Brooklyn, August 27, 1776”
version.description: An 18th-century Charleville musket, a three-pound cannon and Coehorn mortar are among the artifacts on display in this permanent exhibit devoted to the Revolutionary War.

version.name: Punch Up Your Life
version.description: Pete Holmes brings jokes, silliness, overly intimate personal stories and top comedians to this weekly show.

version.name: Hatha I
version.description:
The class moves at a moderate pace, with very descriptive instruction and a focus on breathing techniques, posture and the recitation of Sanskrit prayer. Although the poses are not held for long periods of time, they are gentle and followed by brief relaxation respites. Just walking down 13th Street, approaching the Integral Yoga Institute, I felt like I was on the path to health and wellness: The Institute not only houses three floors of studio space, but also lines the block with a natural-foods market and an apothecary. Hatha I was an excellent introduction to this yoga sanctuary, and provided very thorough instruction in an extremely meditative setting. I didn’t get much of an athletic workout, but still reaped benefits: The class was soothing yet invigorating, and left me with clarity and peace of mind.—Allison Duda
Level: Yoga newbies can do it.
Schedule varies, please check website for details.

version.name: Hatha Yoga: Deep Relaxation
version.description: You may be lucky enough to have a job these days, but those high unemployment numbers probably mean you’re extra bogged down at work. Wind down every Friday with a peaceful, gratis 45-minute yoga class. The session begins with gentle stretching, then moves on to a long period of yoga nidra (deep relaxation) and concludes with breathing practices and a brief meditation. It’s helpful for those without jobs too.

version.name: Complimentary yoga for veterans
version.description: As a small thank-you for the life-threatening services war veterans have provided, Integral Yoga Institute will offer vets weekly complimentary yoga classes to help reduce stress.

version.name: “Mission to Mars”
version.description: Human travel to Mars may still be a pipe dream, but space geeks can visit the Intrepid for a closer look at the vehicles that have been to the Red Planet. This exhibit features a scale model of NASA’s Mars rovers, and examines the current space program.

version.name: The Comedy Dungeon
version.description: Randy Epley invites comics to perform inside this Morningside Heights hostel.

version.name: Gnarly Simon Comedy Hour
version.description: Comedians Jiwon Lee, Claudia Cogan and Ray DeVito cohost a weekly comedy show featuring stand-up, storytelling and occasionally music.

version.name: Joschi Flow 1
version.description:
No chanting, no speeches—instead, instructor Joschi Schwarz calls out the fast-moving sequences and poses in ways that make sense. This was like a dance class, with great contemporary lounge music. At times, I couldn’t keep up (I’m inexperienced with yoga, and maybe a little physically incapable right now), but the participants were a fun group of regulars welcoming and not competitive. I left feeling more bendy and pretty knackered—though a lot of other people looked like they were ready to keep going.—Moira Brazier
Level: Some experience helps.

version.name: Comedy at KFBK
version.description: The smooth and delightfully understated Hannibal Buress, who’s now in the middle of his first season writing for SNL, finds time to bring friends and cohorts out to this new Brooklyn base of a Manhattan staple.

version.name: Kula Flow
version.description:
Movement through the poses at a comfortable pace. The crowd is full of regulars, with a bit of a competitive air. Potentially owing to the downtown location, there were a lot of young professionals at this handsome candlelit studio—the class was mostly populated by young, attractive women between the ages of 25 and 40. While it was not too difficult to keep up, and the poses were fairly standard, the class moved at a decent clip, providing a good workout. Still, there was nothing especially creative about the flow; we progressed through standard floor exercises, followed by postures using the wall for support. And the class was rather crowded, with a foot or two of space between me and my neighbors. A nice touch came at the end, when the instructor, came around and gave every student a very brief head massage with scented oil.—T.J. Carlin
Level: Some experience helps.

version.name: Open Yoga
version.description:
Instructor Melissa spent a good 15 minutes at the outset on breathing and posture, with some light om’ing. Then she picked up the pace with pose sequences, including warrior 1 and 2 and chaturanga (push-up position), but nothing ever felt rushed. Melissa only pushed people as far as they were willing to go, and she offered alternative poses for the less advanced. In the last half hour, we used straps to work on basic headstands and shoulder stands. The winning feature of this class was its size: nine of us altogether in the sparse but cozy street-level studio. I was the only newbie, but the atmosphere was familiar, and it never felt awkward when the instructor called out my name to correct my form…and it was more entertaining than embarrassing when she had to come over and untangle me from my strap. Melissa’s soothing words (“Let the breath massage your insides”) make for an incredibly relaxing experience, even when the poses had me wrapped around myself like a twist tie.—Alex Schechter
Level: Some experience helps.

version.name: Lower East Side Walking Tour
version.description: Think Orchard Street is all about happy hour? Take a stroll through the LES on this tour highlighting the role of retail in the neighborhood’s rich history.

version.name: Midnight Yoga
version.description: It might be the opposite of midnight madness: Every Friday night, Laughing Lotus features live music and vinyasa flow. Seems like a healthy way to ring in the weekend.

version.name: Flower Hour
version.description:
Be prepared for quick movement through poses, focusing on flow and stretching rather than acrobatics. This class was packed wall-to-wall with Lululemon disciples the morning after Thanksgiving, and there’s a reason why: The pacing was rigorous but the workout was basic and comfortable, emphasizing standing poses and pleasing spinal stretches, with forays into intermediate balance work. (Although there was sporadic headstanding, you won’t feel bad if you must stay grounded.) The instructor, Emily Stone, a fiction M.F.A., was hands-off but “on” at all times, bookending the class with comic monologues about self-acceptance: Joy Behar goes Bikram. Recommended for the weekend-warrior yogi who likes their practice serious but unintimidating.—Michael Martin
Level: Some experience helps.

version.name: Le Scandal
version.description: This weekly variety show offers eye-filling visions of New York’s finest new-burlesque artists. Expect fan dancing, magic tricks and other amusements.

event.name: The After Party with Brandon Cutrell

version.name: The After Party with Brandon Cutrell
version.description: This open-mike musical-theater night gives a chance to anyone with a song in his or her heart and, ideally, a few drinks in his or her gut. Mischievous MC Brandon Cutrell often seems like a creature of pure bounce; Gabrielle Stravelli and Becca Johnson lend vocal support, with the proficient Ray Fellman at the keys.

event.name: “Publishing in Exile: German-Language Literature in the U.S. in the 1940s”

version.name: “Publishing in Exile: German-Language Literature in the U.S. in the 1940s”
version.description: Presented in conjunction with the Goethe-Institut New York, this exhibit collects the work of German writers who lived in exile in the United States during World War II. Presses like Pazifische Presse and Pantheon Books were able to publish work by Thomas Mann and Bertolt Brecht, among others.

version.name: Hatha with Oceana Baity
version.description:
You’ll move through sequences at a moderate pace, holding many of the poses for one to two minutes. The class is invigorating, but not exhausting, and the instructor circulates through the room to adjust students’ positions. The class incorporates breathing exercises, props (blocks, blankets, belts) and repeated sequences, with the option to increase or decrease the difficulty level in some of the poses. The class begins and ends with collective oms. Baity’s Tuesday hatha class is for yogis who may be out of practice but are familiar with traditional asanas. She provides clear instruction, even counting the number of breaths for each position, without inserting spiritual or ideological content. The class I attended did not include inversions or advanced positions, but Baity suggested more challenging variations for those who want to “up-level” their practice. She demonstrated how to align the body in a specific way (e.g., tuck in the tailbone to avoid lower-back compression) and circulated around the room to offer individual adjustments. When I was in downward dog, she applied pressure to my sacrum, helping me lengthen the pose and stretch my lower back. You’ll leave feeling refreshed, not exhausted, and quite possibly tempted by the Silver Moon Bakery just below the studio.—Shayna D. Skarf
Level: Some experience helps.
version.price: Single class $18, first class $10, packages available

version.name: London Sole
version.description: In a mod midtown space, this by-appointment London-based boutique offers faux-crocodile driving shoes, gold-ribboned flats and more—all a stiletto-free step in the right direction.

version.name: Gutterball Lounge & Discotheque
version.description: Cabaret and fashion darlings Lady Rizo and Shien Lee cohost this ode to the boogie nights of the past, brought to you by none other than Lee Chappell. DJs Michael T. and Steve Sidewalk spin, while the avant-garde offer live performances, digital projections and art installations.

version.name: Basics Class
version.description:
Chanting and a spiritual talk, followed by a challenging yet manageable class. The group was made up of the same people I see at the Cobble Hill Trader Joe’s, ranging in age from 20 to 60. The class began with everyone in seated position, as the instructor discussed the spiritual meaning of yoga, at one point relating a parable about a snake and some other animal. (No, I wasn’t really paying attention.) After some chanting, we moved through poses fairly quickly, returning to either downward dog or tabletop pose as rest positions. The teacher moved about frequently, correcting poses, or placing padded blocks under the hands of the people who weren’t flexible enough to touch the floor while bending over. Due to warm weather and an overactive radiator, the room was very hot the afternoon I went, making the whole thing feel a bit like Bikram yoga. The instructor started off slowly enough, so that even I, a neophyte, could easily follow. But then she suddenly began to accelerate the pace; it took a lot of concentration to keep up, especially when she started throwing around yoga lingo and anatomical terminology (femur, thoracic cavity). Also, while generous with encouragement, she addressed us in a tone that reminded me of someone talking to their pet. Still, I never became completely lost, and neither, it seemed, did anyone else—meaning the class is good for both beginners and more regular yogi types.—Howard Halle
Level: Yoga newbies can do it.
Schedule varies, please check website for details.

version.name: Permanent collection
version.description: This summer, MOCA finally opens its Maya Lin–designed space on Centre Street to the public. Visitors can tour the permanent collection, which includes artifacts like opera costumes from the Chinese Music and Theatrical Association, dresses made in China during the ’30s and ’40s, and archival photographs of Chinese immigrants.
version.property: MOCA’s former space on Mulberry Street closed last year, making way for this brand-new space on the edge of Chinatown. Designed by Vietnam Veterans Memorial architect Maya Lin, the building incorporates organic elements such as bronze walls, reclaimed wood floors and a giant skylight that illuminates its two-floor atrium. The Chinese-American experience is the main focus of the permanent collection, but the additional gallery space allows for more contemporary programming—including a survey of contemporary Chinese-American artists and a series of short films set in Chinatown.

event.name: “With a Single Step: Stories in the Making of America”

version.name: “With a Single Step: Stories in the Making of America”
version.description: The museum’s core exhibit looks at the relationship between China and the USA. Six different mini exhibits look at different stages in the development of the Chinese community in the States, including the various influxes of emigration from China in the 19th and 20th centuries. Another component, titled “Made in America?!?,” looks at the impact of globalization on each country.

version.name: The Keeping History Center
version.description: The museum’s new permanent installation is an interactive experience, featuring the stories of immigrants to the United States who fled oppression (like Holocaust survivors and Soviet refuseniks). Visitors listen to these stories on a provided iPod Touch.

version.name: “The Morgenthaus: A Legacy of Service”
version.description: As Manhattan District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau prepares to step down after 34 years in office, the museum looks at both his and his family’s legacy of public service. His father, Henry Morgenthau Jr., served as the Secretary of the Treasury under FDR, while his grandfather Henry Morgenthau Sr. was the U.S. ambassador to the Ottoman Empire during World War I.

version.name: Garden of Stones
version.description: For his first permanent commission in NYC, artist Andy Goldsworthy created a contemplative garden of narrow pathways formed by 18 boulders, from which dwarf oak saplings grow.

version.name: “Action: Sex and the Moving Image”
version.description: From early Edison reels to clips from recent fare like The Brown Bunny and Brokeback Mountain, sexuality’s impact on mainstream cinema (as well as television and the Internet) is explored in the museum’s second gallery. The adult-film industry’s enduring presence is made evident through early stag films (or “smokers,” as they were called) and porn classics like Debbie Does Dallas.

event.name: “Rubbers: The Life, History and Struggle of the Condom”

version.name: “Rubbers: The Life, History and Struggle of the Condom”
version.description: Love glove, Willie warmer, French letter, English overcoat: Whatever you call it, a condom is an essential bedside tool. This exhibit examines the history and development of the contraceptive, covering topics like its use in the military, condom distribution among the elderly, and the condom as a political-awareness device. Appropriately, the exhibit is sponsored by Trojan.

version.name: Museum of the Moving Image
version.description: For information on the museum’s varied series of screenings, see Film, Art-house & indie cinema.

version.name: National Jean Company
version.description: Fresh reinforcements in the Holy Grail–like quest for a pair of well-fitting dungarees have arrived from this Long Island chain’s UES emporium. More than 3,000 pairs of women’s jeans ($180–$350) overflow from ceiling-to-floor shelves, spilling neatly onto tables and dressing-room benches. You’ll find all the usual denim brands like 7 for All Mankind, along with coveted labels such as J Brand and Pierce. If the massive selection proves too dizzying, the appropriately named jeans expert Jean-Luc can help you determine which trends and silhouettes best complement your body.

version.name: “A Song for the Horse Nation”
version.description: In Native American culture, horses aren’t just animals; they provide transportation, spur economic growth and act as companions. This exhibit uses artifacts like paintings, clothing and more to illustrate the horse’s influence on Native cultures.

version.name: Wall Street Walking Tour
version.description: This storied neighborhood was the birthplace of both urban America and our nation’s financial structure. Stops include Trinity Church, the U.S. Custom House and the New York Stock Exchange.

version.name: Million Dollar Quartet
version.description: Just when it seemed like the much-maligned Broadway jukebox musical was played out, here comes a harmlessly rollicking diversion, ostensibly set at the famous 1956 Sun Records jam session among early rockers Elvis Presley, Johnny Cash, Jerry Lee Lewis and Carl Perkins. Each star sings a few of his greatest hits in a what resembles a live extension of the Madame Tussauds museum a block away. The jam is spread a little thin, but Levi Kreis gives a killer performance as the florid piano showman Lewis.—AF

version.name: Cuerpaso
version.description: The experience: How do you say “Holy soccer balls, that hurts” en español? You’ll be searching for the answer during this relentless workout that blends Latin-Caribbean dance moves with soccer-inspired athletic drills. Cuerpaso, which means “the ultimate body” in Spanish, is the brainchild of trainer Tadeo Arnold, who created the high-intensity exercises (rotating squats, jumping toe touches, etc.) to burn fat and sculpt lean muscle. If this is how Brazilian models get their killer beach bods, I don’t resent them, because they’ve certainly worked hard for it. How fit you need to be: Fitness freak.—Cristina Velocci

version.name: Vinyasa - All levels
version.description:
Vinyasa flow at a relaxed pace; lots of teacher attention and a brief chanting and speech session. Class began with a meditative pose, in which we were told to hold as still and quiet as possible—a worthy challenge in the middle of a typically harrowing New York City day. My relaxation was disrupted, however, when the chanting began. Luckily, the awkward vocal calisthenics lasted onlyfor about five minutes, and we got on to the tough part of class: stretching out those stiff muscles and sweating out last night’s takeout. I appreciated the chill vibe of the instructor and the fact that she individualized my workout so that I felt some muscle soreness the next day, but no real exhaustion to speak of.—Blair Tidwell
Level: Yoga newbies can do it.

version.name: Hot Soup!
version.description: There’s only one thing we can see lacking in this weekly stand-up show—curated by Matt Ruby, Mark Normand, Andy Haynes and David Cope—and that’s a new flavor of soup each week.

version.name: Oasis Day Spa’s Wellness Wednesdays
version.description: Break up the workweek with a facial and an aromatherapy massage. During the 75-minute face treatment, pure vitamin C patches are applied to your cheeks, forehead and chin and then massaged into the skin with seaweed for hydration and brightness. The hour-long Swedish massage calms with the aromas of essential oils. TGIW.

version.name: Haiku, a Comedy Show
version.description: Daniel Mahoney hosts stand-ups in the lounge of this popular pub. (Don’t count the syllables in this listing; we didn’t go there.)

version.name: Stomp
version.description: This shrewd garbage heap of clog dancing, prop comedy and chest-thumping percussion spins out an impressive (if numbing) number of variations of its vaudeville act by way of English punk.—DC

version.name: Shrink
version.description: Sharon “Mama” Spell hosts local up-and-coming comics.

version.name: Panetta Movement Center
version.description: Classes:•Technique. Lance Gries: Through Fri 29. 10am–noon. $15. •Research Workshop. Lance Gries: Mon, Tue, Fri 12:30–2:30pm. Showing Feb 12 at 8:30pm. Free.

version.name: Vinyasa Open Class
version.description:
The class starts and ends with some basic Sanskrit chanting, nothing too overwhelming. In between, it’s like aerobicized yoga with minimal instruction: You move through the poses very quickly and work up a killer sweat. If you’ve done yoga before, you’ll catch on quickly, but this is definitely not for beginners. As a hatha habitué, I was shocked by the pace of vinyasa, flying through poses without much emphasis on hitting them perfectly. I was literally dripping sweat throughout the 90 minutes and had to take a few breaks (luckily, I wasn’t the only one). However, without much instruction, I found myself looking around the room to see what I should be doing pretty often—no way is this class for beginners. The vibe was very yoga, though, laid-back and comfortable. If I did this class once a week, I’d be in the best shape of my life—I’ll definitely be going back.—Beth Levendis
Level: Some experience helps.
version.price: Single class $18, first class $10, packages available

version.name: Salsa with the Baila Society
version.description: Two teachers lead this intimate, completely unintimidating dance lesson, so you can be sure to get all the attention you’ll need in order to master the basics of ballroom salsa. Having broken a sweat in the first hour of solo choreographed moves, you’ll switch to less strenuous but equally fun instruction with a partner of the opposite sex (you’ll rotate, so no need to be nervous about choosing someone). How fit you need to be: Couch potatoes welcome—Kate Lowenstein

version.name: Peridance Capezio Center
version.description: Classes:•Absolute-beginner tap. Tony Mayes: Mon 7:30–8:30pm. •Advanced-intermediate ballet. Susan Jaffe: Mon, Fri 11:30am–1pm. •Advanced-intermediate contemporary. Max Stone: Tue, Thu, Fri 1–2:30pm. •Intermediate ballet. Kenny Larson: Mon, Wed, Fri 4–5:30pm. •Intermediate contemporary jazz. Wes Veldink: Tue, Thu 8–9:30pm. •Intermediate Graham. Armgard von Bardeleben: Mon, Wed 11:30am–1pm. •Intermediate Taylor-based modern. Lisa Viola: Mon, Wed, Fri 2:30–4pm. •Intermediate urban lyrical jazz. Diego Funes: Tue, Thu 2:30–4pm; Sat noon–1:30pm. •Introduction to ballet. Bill Badolato: Tue, Thu 8:30–9:45pm. •Open vinyasa yoga. Amy Pivar: Mon–Fri 9–10am. •Open wackin’ and voguing. Archie: Tue, Thu, Fri 8:30–10pm. •Open Zena Rommett Floor Barre. LuAnn Leonard: Wed 11am–noon. •Professional ballet. Igal Perry: Mon–Fri 10–11:30am.

version.name: Smartass
version.description: DJ Spookypants hosts this weekly rock-trivia night, where the competition is as stiff as the drinks being given away as prizes.

version.name: Sunday Night Comedy at Pianos
version.description: Newcomers and pros mix it up in this weekly stand-up showcase hosted by Dave Rosinsky.

version.name: Plaza Too
version.description: The West Village’s mallification continues via this Westchester accessories chain’s second Manhattan emporium, which gathers Gryson handbags ($800–$1,000), Kors Michael Kors heels ($200–$400) and CC Skye bangles ($180), among other tony loot.

version.name: The Living Room
version.description: Luke Thayer and Abbi Crutchfield present an hour of stand-up with underground comics, special guests and mock news.

version.name: Prana Mandir Midtown Yoga Studio
version.description: Take an hour-long bliss break midday or a 90-minute class after work with classic vinyasa and kundalini classes taught by well-known instructor Lea Kraemer, among others. Mention TONY and your first class is $5 (regularly $10).
version.property: Call or see website for schedule.

version.name: Partner Yoga
version.description: Instead of using alcohol to qualm first-date nervousness, try something a little unexpected: Bring a date to this unique yoga class designed for two. Through a sequence of postures, you’ll “find your center and strengthen your core” while releasing stress (and any jitters!). Partner yoga creates an expanded state of awareness through sensitivity, balance, trust, breath and focus. And hey, it’s cheaper than a round of drinks at a bar! All skill levels are welcome.

version.name: Hot Vinyasa Flow Yoga
version.description:
Standard vinyasa flow in a 90–97°F room. The instructor corrects your form and gives you a mini massage while you’re in child’s pose. There’s a bit of om-ing, but nothing too over-the-top. This clean, modern studio is Alan Cumming’s favorite yoga spot, but it’s no hoity-toity celeb hang: Warm, attentive teachers encourage noncompetitiveness and remind you to go into child’s pose whenever things get too difficult. The emphasis here is on your practice and what feels right—even if that means just lying there. This is a great place to try hot yoga for the first time.—Corinne Mohr
Level: Yoga newbies can do it.

version.name: Basics Yoga
version.description:
The teachers at this small, brownstone-apartment studio are serious about yoga: You will experience some om’ing at the beginning and end of your session, and the instructors will push you to improve your practice. But they are also lighthearted, even funny; everyone there seems to enjoy themselves. Instructor David Figueroa starts the Basics class slowly, allowing students to warm up and fine-tune particular positions. With description, demonstration and physical assistance, he helps paticipants with each pose. After that, he increases the pace, helping you not just with the poses but with the transitions between them. I’ve tried a number of yoga basics classes, but this is the first one that I want to return to. The vibe is relaxed, and the instructors are great at helping you find positions that at first seem counterintuitive (and at helping you breathe, something I often forget to do). As a workout, it was hard—some poses made me shake (no doubt because they required the use of muscles my body had long ago left for dead). But it was also a great stretch (much needed: I run) and, for all its demands, deeply relaxing. By the end, when we assumed the corpse pose on our mats, I felt both energized and like I was about to melt into the floorboards.—Michael Miller
Level: Yoga newbies can do it.

version.name: Will Power & Grace
version.description: The experience: The hour flew by, surprisingly. Focusing on form over pace, this shoeless session moves through a series of simple but lunge-heavy stances that challenge your balance and stamina. The legs get worked—constantly lunging and squatting, as the rest of your body turns, stretches and lifts. There are three levels of skill, and though I stayed at the lowest one, the next day I could barely walk. The class was upbeat, and the drills switched quickly enough so as to not become unbearable. Plus, I loved being barefoot, because it added an awareness to form that wouldn’t have been possible with shoes. How fit you need to be: Gym regular.—Francesca Soroka

version.name: Slow Flow
version.description:
This vinyasa practice takes students through familiar poses at a reduced pace, giving you time to explore—if not achieve—proper form. During extended holds, teaching assistants carefully adjust your posture or spot someone with wobbly equilibrium (students may opt out of adjustments by raising a hand before class). The instructor’s narrative was informative and encouraging in the best way: no cloying inspirational bromides here; instead, you’ll get a real-world pep talk on letting go of petty stresses and reconnecting with your core strength in body and mind. Having just moved myself into a new apartment, I walked into this popular class nursing bruised, sore muscles and utility-company-induced rage. The studio was unusually crowded—grr. With the students’ negativity crackling like static electricity, the instructor firmly directed us to transform any irritation and absorb the energy of the bodies surrounding us. As we moved through a sequence of challenging but mostly achievable postures, I found myself alternating between confronting my physical limits and relaxing into asanas I’d previously mastered (thank you, triangle pose!). When the instructor made a gentle wisecrack about focusing our gaze on the Lululemon logo currently stuck on the butt in our faces, I laughed out loud—and earned a wink in return. By the end, I was sweaty, invigorated and eager to return for another emotional rescue.—Maureen Shelly
Level: Some experience helps; advanced yogis will be challenged too.

version.name: Slow Flow
version.description:
This vinyasa practice takes students through familiar poses at a reduced pace, giving you time to explore—if not achieve—proper form. During extended holds, teaching assistants carefully adjust your posture or spot someone with wobbly equilibrium (students may opt out of adjustments by raising a hand before class). The instructor’s narrative was informative and encouraging in the best way: no cloying inspirational bromides here; instead, you’ll get a real-world pep talk on letting go of petty stresses and reconnecting with your core strength in body and mind. Having just moved myself into a new apartment, I walked into this popular class nursing bruised, sore muscles and utility-company-induced rage. The studio was unusually crowded—grr.
