As we moved through a sequence of challenging but mostly achievable postures, I found myself alternating between confronting my physical limits and relaxing into asanas I’d previously mastered (thank you, triangle pose!). When the instructor made a gentle wisecrack about focusing our gaze on the Lululemon logo currently stuck on the butt in our faces, I laughed out loud—and earned a wink in return. By the end, I was sweaty, invigorated and eager to return for another emotional rescue.—Maureen Shelly
Level: Some experience helps; advanced yogis will be challenged too.
Schedule varies, please check website for details.

version.name: Queens Botanical Garden
version.property: The garden’s 39 acres offer views of the New York State Pavilion and the Unisphere, built for the 1964 World’s Fair.

version.name: Queens Zoo
version.property: Traversing habitats from the Great Plains to the woodlands of the Northeast, zoogoers encounter the richness of animal life in the U.S., including mountain lions, bald eagles, Roosevelt elk and the American bison.

version.name: The Last Supper
version.description: Dan Rosen’s black comedy offers up a Swiftian solution to the party of no: A liberal batch of roommates host dinner parties at which they dispatch their conservative guests—permanently. Akia Squitieri directs.

version.name: Fierce Aerial Conditioning
version.description: The experience: The trapeze wasn’t as daunting as the 30-foot silk ropes hanging from the ceiling, though instructor Fran Sperling’s direction quelled any nervousness. We were working on the bar in no time and quickly escalated to miniature routines. The trick is physics—as long as you can hold your own body weight, you can perform on the trapeze; doing somersaults, leg lifts, faux splits. Sperling believes inversion is “the fountain of youth” for its circulation and breathing benefits; I’d agree, because it felt like playing instead of working out. How fit you need to be: Occasional exerciser. Registration required, contact Fran Sperling at 212-501-1401, ext 3890, or fsper@mp-trainer.com—Francesa Soroka

version.name: Stoked 360
version.description:
What to expect: A mixture of cardiovascular exercises (think running and jump roping) and strength-building exercises like lunges, weights, push-ups and crunches.
Instructor Kira Stokes did a great job of motivating and energizing her students (most of whom were regulars), and the constantly changing activities will definitely get you sweating. Unfortunately, the class’s scattershot approach is also its downfall; just as you get the rhythm of one set, Stokes moves on to something else. And though Reebok’s schedule indicates the class is 75 minutes, we busted our asses for nearly 90.—Christy Purington
How in shape you need to be: Gym regular

version.name: Stretch, Flow & Fly
version.description:
Class opens with the participants sitting in a circle, introducing themselves and answering a question (we were asked, “When you’re reincarnated, what will you come back as?”). Then they warm up in assigned pairs, engaging in traditional poses and some yoga-inflected conditioning. After a quick instruction, groups of three (a base, a flyer and a spotter) work at their own pace through various inverted yoga poses. For instance, the base lies on her back, using her feet to support the flyer’s hips, while the flyer hangs her head toward the floor. Returning to pairs, participants give one another a prolonged Thai yoga massage. I was initially anxious, but a friend assured me that AcroYoga is “just a lot of airplanes and massage.” She was not far off. I was especially challenged by the conditioning warm-up, and the rest was just fun. The inversions are tailored to your skill level (as a newcomer, I mostly hung upside down and tried to avoid putting my face in my partner’s crotch) and are often accompanied by light massage; in other words, I wouldn’t call it strenuous. Unlike most yoga classes, this one is accompanied by upbeat, popular music, and the instructors are boisterous. Still, chanting, harnessing energy and a whole lot of hands-on activities are major parts of the class, so don’t attend thinking you’ll be your own meditative island. Prepare to touch and be touched. A lot. The Thai massage, which my partner described as “the really yummy part,” is a relaxing, therapeutic way to end the evening, and I went home feeling cozy and not at all sore.—Heather Moore
Level: Yoga newbies can do it.
Schedule varies, please check website for details.

version.name: Restore Spa’s Remedy Nail Lounge
version.description: Sandal weather is winding down, but that’s no excuse to let your feet go. With such offerings as the blade-free callus-removing Pamper-and-Go Pedicure (45 minutes for $25) and the sandalwood-and-calendula–enriched Pure Earth Pedicure ($85 for 75 minutes), you might have reason to invest in nice-looking dogs year ’round.

version.name: Restore Spa’s Electromagnetic facial
version.description: Wage war against your wrinkles with Restore Spa’s 120-minute electromagnetic facial. Albert Garcia first applies micromagnets to the face in an effort to supply damage-repairing energy to problem areas. Afterward, Janis Chakler treats the skin with an oxygen blast and a multieffect treatment enzyme. Ta-ta, crow’s-feet.

version.name: Rockefeller Center
version.property: Simon & Schuster, McGraw-Hill and other media giants inhabit this Art Deco city-within-a-city, while “Top of the Rock,” Rockefeller Center’s 70th-floor observation deck, offers panoramic views of Manhattan (topoftherocknyc.com; $20, seniors $18, children 6–12 $13, children under 6 free). Guided tours of the complex leave every hour: Mon–Sat 11am–5pm; Sun 11am–4pm ($12, seniors and children over 6 $10, children under 6 not admitted). Don't freak out if you run into Andy Samberg or Conan O'Brien on the NBC Studios tour, which departs every half hour Mon–Thu 8:30am–4:30pm, and every 15 minutes Fri, Sat 9:30am–5:30pm, and Sun 9:30am–4:30pm ($18.50, seniors and children 6–12 $15.50, children under 6 not admitted).

version.name: 31 Rock Comedy Tuesdays
version.description: Dave Lester hosts this weekly showcase at a Brooklyn club with a full menu at patrons’ fingertips.

version.name: K2 Lounge
version.description: Celebrate the end of the workweek at the Rubin Museum’s happy-hour party, featuring cocktails and appetizers, live music, DJs, free tours and talks.

version.name: “Visions of the Cosmos”
version.description: Eastern and Western perspectives on our universe come together in this exhibition, which features works of art as well as photographic images from the Hubble Space Telescope. Through May 10.

version.name: “Bardo: Tibetan Art of the Afterlife”
version.description: These paintings, sculptures and artifacts all relate to the spiritual afterlife of the Tibetan dead. Through Sept 6.

version.name: WordPlay
version.description: If reading is fundamental, the Rubin puts the accent on the first syllable (that’s fun, for those of you playing along at home). This weekly program helps kids work on their literacy skills and listening comprehension, using interactive storytelling, gallery exploration, songs, dance, puppet plays and Himalayan-themed books. Ages 3 to 5.

version.name: Sexy Fresh
version.description: DJs MK and Mike da Wizard reign at this Loca Entertainment fiesta, with dancing, drink specials, and plenty of eye candy for both boys and girls.

version.name: $5 Fridays/Breakout
version.description: The name of this night at the towering Chelsea twink haunt says it all: Five bucks gets you in the door, and that’s also the cost of beer and well drinks (if you’re over 21). A second party shares the space at Rush: Breakout—the fantasy side of the night—brought to you by Dina Delicious, King Ralphy, Miss Alixandria and DJ John Marto.

version.name: Scoop
version.description: This self-titled “Mega Scoop” (one of three in the city from founder Stefani Greenfield and Uzi Ben-Abraham, though are a slew across the country) is a block wide, providing ample space for a host of lines such as Jovovich Hawk, Diane von Furstenberg and Tory Burch. Much like a mini department store (it is 10,000 square feet), women are the primary target (you can snag everything from basic jeans and t-shirts to jewel bedecked gowns), though there are pieces for mini-trendsetters (including Lucy Sykes' kid adorable collection) and men as well.

version.name: Scout
version.description: David to Loehmann’s Goliath, labels-for-less trove Scout is small in size but mighty in discounts. Top-shelf ladies’ threads—Alvin Valley coats, tops and pants and Missoni sandals, among others—are up to 80 percent below retail.

event.name: Sea Change New York: Exploring the Community

version.name: Sea Change New York: Exploring the Community
version.description: Join Dr. Louis Abate on the third Saturday of each month for a bike tour of the city, making occasional stops for refreshments and chatting. While exploring New York—and building a community of friends in the process—the good doctor will enlighten travelers about their bodies and wellness. All levels of bikers are welcome.

version.name: Yoga Beginners
version.description:
Slow, easy vinyasa; basic, simple poses; breathing exercises; no chanting, lecture or dogma. I’ve done yoga at the gym on and off for years, but have avoided studios, because long chanting sessions and thinking about my third eye (or whatever) makes my brain itch. So I was quite relieved when my class instructor, Teresa von Fuchs, started cracking jokes early on—mostly about how crowded the room was (“This is the part where you get to clobber your neighbor’s arm,” she said at one point). Aside from the tight fit in the small room, the class was great: It moved quickly enough that slightly more experienced yogis could find a challenge, but there was plenty of space for amateurs to slow down and take it easy. It was a friendly, relaxed environment, and it definitely broke me of my yoga-studio-phobia.—Ethan LaCroix
Level: Yoga newbies can do it.
Schedule varies, please check website for details.

version.name: Memphis
version.description: Now that Broadway no longer benefits from Hairspray’s retro uplift, there’s room for another musical about the racial integration of a television dance program in the early years of the civil-rights movement. Joe DiPietro and David Bryan’s score has its heart and soul music in the right place, and the production features a dynamic leading performance by Chad Kimball and a strong vocal one by Montego Glover. But this kind of single-minded musical requires greater depth and range of color than DiPietro, Bryan and director Christopher Ashley have mustered.—AF

version.name: Sir
version.description: The sewing machines, fabric swatches and spools of thread aren't just pretty decorative elements at this boutique: RISD graduate and designer Joanna Baum employs them to create her retro raw-edge dresses here. Lasses tired of superfemme creations can also find jackets and blouses with menswear-inspired details, along with a small selection of accessories.

version.name: Sir
version.description: The sewing machines, fabric swatches and spools of thread aren't just pretty decorative elements at this boutique: RISD graduate and designer Joanna Baum employs them to create her retro raw-edge dresses here. Lasses tired of superfemme creations can also find jackets and blouses with menswear-inspired details, along with a small selection of accessories.

version.name: Open class
version.description:
This session begins and ends with a nice lie-down, complemented by soothing chanting, courtesy of the instructor and anyone else who knows the words. (It’s sort of like a really good relaxation CD.) Next is a series of regimented breathing exercises (warning: it’ll get messy if you have a cold), followed by the main program: a moderate routine of stretching-related movements, all of which are held long enough and performed with enough repetition to give beginners a feel for the position before everyone’s moved on. It’s not just about the class itself at the Sivananda center—the whole place sets a tone of relaxation. You enter a brownstone on a quiet Chelsea street and are welcomes by a calming scene—people chatting in indoor voices, staff members dressed in super-comfortable pants, and yogis eating vegetarian meals out in an open kitchen (meals are served Monday and Tuesday at 7:30pm and Saturdays at noon; $12, members $10). The classrooms have low lighting and some enviable feng shui, and my instructor was completely welcoming and happy to help me through the exercises. While newcomers are best off at a beginners’ class (Sat 12:15pm), they should get enough individual attention in the open classes to be able to keep up. That said, Sivananda yoga moves slowly, and is not for ADD types or people who need to perspire profusely to be satisfied with their workout. I didn’t feel like I’d earned a five-course meal or anything, but I had more energy going out than coming in, and my hamstrings and back felt thoroughly stretched.—Chris Schonberger
Level: Yoga newbies can do it.
Schedule varies, please check website for details.

version.name: Sky Rink
version.description: This Chelsea Piers rink is the nicest—and most expensive—in the city. No wonder it’s Brian Boitano’s favorite practice area when he visits.

version.name: Indoor Rowing
version.description: The experience: After an introduction to the rowing apparatus and proper form, the lively instructor pushed our small class (only three people allowed per session) through 45 minutes of nonstop rowing. Because of the personalized attention, I probably worked harder than I would have on my own, and learned that just moving my arms can provide a great ab workout. How fit you need to be: Occasional exerciser.—Francesca Soroka

version.name: Smoke Big Band
version.description: Reedist Bill Mobley fires up a new pack of locals.

version.name: Chris Washburne and SYOTOS
version.description: Music scholar Chris Washburne’s Latin-jazz band heats up Sundays at Smoke.

version.name: Hammond B-3 Organ Grooves
version.description: Most of the participants in this soulful weekly gig make their living on the postbop circuit, but here, with a big B-3 in the house, the proceedings are always about groovy jazz. Mike LeDonne is often at the helm.

version.name: The Fantasticks
version.description: Whatever magic this semiprecious 1960 musical must once have had is in woefully short supply in this flimsy tourist-trap revival. The show’s earnestly whimsical tone has not aged well, and the whole enterprise seems to have been lifted from a musty old trunk and plunked down in an equally musty new one: the shabby Snapple Theater Center.—AF

event.name: Klea Blackhurst: Everything the Traffic Will Allow

version.name: Klea Blackhurst: Everything the Traffic Will Allow
version.description: This one’s a real treat: The boisterous, trumpet-voiced Klea Blackhurst reprises her sensational 2001 tribute to Ethel Merman, which earned her a TONY MAC award. Selections include “I Got Rhythm,” “Blow, Gabriel, Blow” and “Everything’s Coming Up Roses.”

version.name: Perfect Crime
version.description: A wily cop tries to psych out a possibly homicidal shrink in Warren Manzi’s moldy, convoluted mystery. The creaky welter of dime-store Freudianism, noirish attitude and whodunit gimmickry is showing its age. (Catherine Russell has starred since 1987.)—DC

version.name: Soho Dance Studio
version.description: Classes: •Advanced-beginner salsa. Mon 8:30–9:30pm; Wed 6:30–7:30pm. •Beginner salsa on 1. Mon 6:30–7:30pm. •Beginner salsa on 2. Tue, Thu 8:30–9:30pm; Sat 1:30–2:30pm. •Intro to Latin ballroom. Tue 6:30–7:30pm. •Open Argentine tango. Wed 7:30–8:30pm. •Open belly dancing. Fri 8:30–9:30pm. •Open break dancing. Wed 8:30–9:30pm. •Open hip-hop. Wed 7:30–8:30pm. •Open Hustle. Tue 7:30–8:30pm. •Open Latin club dance. Thu 7:30–8:30pm. •Open Zumba. Mon 7:30–8:30pm. •Practice Party. Thu 9:30–10pm.

version.name: Flow 1
version.description:
This class takes yoga to a deeper level by integrating breathing techniques with conscious, free-flowing movement. At first glance, the huge studio and large number of students were intimidating, but once the lights dimmed, the music started and the room settled, a truly intimate setting emerged. While the continuous sequence of standing poses, back bends, twists and lunges was aerobic and vigorous, I was able to easily transition from movement to movement—and when the heat arrived in my muscles and the excessive sweating subsided, my mind cleared and my body calmed. The personal attention and inspiring presence of studio manager and co-director Johanna Aldrich and assistant Kathleen Flanagan were definitely among the most appealing features of this class: Both came over frequently to adjust our poses and assist with stretching, and Aldrich did a great job using visual exercises to keep us going (“Picture a person you love and hold the position for that person”). I highly recommend it to anyone wanting more from yoga than its physical rewards, as this was equally demanding of my mind and my spirit.—Julia Keefe-Chamberlain
Level: Some experience helps.
Schedule varies, please check website for details.

version.name: SoulCycle Signature Class
version.description:
What to expect: A pedaling warm-up, followed by on-bike abdominal and endurance work, and then ten minutes of upper-arm weights done while still pedaling, and finishing with a cooldown
Cycling for your soul? The candlelit spin room won’t quite get you to nirvana, but at least this cardio workout comes without barking from the teacher. The music is upbeat, the instruction is encouraging, and a hand-weights portion means the arms don’t get short shrift. It’s an invigorating sweat, with none of the postcycling soreness that can make spinners walk like cowpokes. When first-timers manage to get the pedaling crunch maneuvers in sync with the rest of the class—which attracts high-profile types such as Chelsea Clinton when we visited—it’s almost transcendent. Almost.—Allison Williams
How in shape you need to be: Occasional exerciser

event.name: New York TV and Movie Tour on the Water

version.name: New York TV and Movie Tour on the Water
version.description: On Location Tours teams up with the New York Water Taxi to bring you this maritime tour of big- and small-screen locales, including sites seen in The Royal Tenenbaums, Law & Order, X-Men, The Godfather, CSI: NY and Superman Returns.

event.name: “Treasures of a President: FDR and the Sea”

version.name: “Treasures of a President: FDR and the Sea”
version.description: This exhibit examines the 32nd President’s passion for the sea, shown through his large collection of naval- and maritime-related artifacts. Prints, books and more than 30 model ships are just some of the pieces on view.

event.name: “DecoDence: Legendary Interiors and Illustrious Travelers Aboard the S.S. Normandie”

version.name: “DecoDence: Legendary Interiors and Illustrious Travelers Aboard the S.S. Normandie”
version.description: Get a glimpse of the luxurious life of an ocean-liner traveler at this exhibit, which looks at the brief—but fancy—career of the S.S. Normandie. Artifacts on view include Art Deco furniture, lush tapestry chairs, and dining sets of crystal and silver.

version.name: Water Works
version.description: The experience: The bulk of this hour is spent jogging, skipping and sashaying around the shallow end of the pool while wearing webbed spandex gloves or holding floats, with frequent changes of direction that force you to fight the current you’ve just created. Instructor “Aqua Dan” shouts out (and mimes) directions, but doesn’t provide a count, allowing everyone to move at his or her own pace. The harder you push yourself, the more resistance you’ll get from the water—and the tougher the workout. How fit you need to be: Couch potatoes welcome.—Amy Roberts

version.name: Wednesgayz
version.description: DJ Tikka hosts this new weekly dance party, with a rotating lineup of hand-selected guest DJs and down-to-earth Bed-Stuy queers.

version.name: Bendyboys
version.description: Designed specifically for the male body, this class for queer men and their friends includes breathing exercises to increase energy and immunity, and restorative poses to rebalance the body and mind.

version.name: “Wall of Insects”
version.description: Get to know moths, beetles, walking sticks and cicadas from all over the world.

version.name: “The Lenape: The First Staten Islanders”
version.description: Learn about one of NYC’s indigenous tribes through pieces that date back as far as 10,000 years.

version.name: Staten Island Zoo
version.property: New York's “biggest little zoo” is an eight-acre haven for southern and eastern African leopards, mandrills, lizards, antelope and lemurs. Face snakes head-on in the “Fear Zone,” part of the zoo's newly renovated Reptile Wing, which opened in 2007. At the children's center, kids can feed domesticated animals such as donkeys, goats, pigs and deer.

version.name: Steps
version.description: Classes: •Advanced-intermediate contemporary jazz. Wes Veldink: Mon, Wed, Fri 11:30am–1pm. •Advanced-intermediate jazz. Lisa Harvie: Mon, Wed 6:15–7:45pm. •Beginning-intermediate ballet. Lonne Moretton: Tue, Thu 11am–12:30pm. David Howard: Mon, Wed 6–7:30pm. •Beginning rumba tap. Max Pollak: Mon, Thu 10–11:30am. •Beginning tap. Bill Coates: Tue 11:30am–1pm. •Beginning theater dance. Scott Thompson: Wed, Sat 1–2:30pm. •Intermediate ballet. Kathleen Smith: Mon, Wed, Fri 10–11:30am. •Intermediate contemporary jazz. Brice: Sun 5–6:30pm. •Intermediate flamenco. Victorio Korjhan: Sun 5–6:30pm. •Intermediate tap improv. Barbara Duffy: Tue 1–2:30pm, Thu 11:30am-1pm. •Intermediate theater dance. Jeff Shade: Mon, Wed 1–2:30pm. •Open Zumba. Misty Clark: Mon, Fri 8–9pm. •Pilates mat. Tim Kasper: Mon 7–8pm. •Rommett Floor Barre. Jodi Moccia: Tue, Thu 10–11:30am.

version.name: España Streb Trapeze Academy
version.description: Classes: •Adult pop action. Thu 6:30–8pm. $15, ten-class card $135.•Adult trampoline. Mon–Thu 7–8:30pm. $25, ten-class card $225.•Advanced trapeze. Mon 6:30–8:30pm, 8:30–10:30pm. $47.50, ten-class card $425.•Beginner flip and tuck. Mon 8:30–10pm. $15, ten-class card $135.•Open flip and tuck. Wed 6–7:30pm. $15, ten-class card $135.

version.name: Studio 5-2/Gibney Dance
version.description: Classes:•Advanced-intermediate ballet. Brian Carey Chung: Wed, Fri 4–6pm.•Dharma yoga. Raphaël Boumaïla: Tue, Thu 8–9:30am.•Open ballet. Giada Ferrone: Sat 2–4pm.•Professional ballet. Christine Wright: Mon–Fri 10am–noon. •Yoga plus/Pilates plus. Rochelle Rice: Tue, Thu 6:15–7:30pm.

version.name: Sweet Lily’s Coconut Pineapple Pedicure
version.description: If you like piña coladas, you might also enjoy this 60-minute treatment, which exfoliates your legs and feet with pineapple juice and cane sugar, moisturizes with coconut oil and finishes with the polish of your choice. Just don’t get caught in the rain while your toenails are still wet.

version.name: MELT
version.description:
This small class, which usually has no more than seven participants, focuses on the connective tissue that stabilizes your body. We used specialized rollers and balls to slowly move through poses that zeroed in on different parts of our anatomy. MELT is like self-massage: Your whole body gets stretched and plied, from the balls of the feet all the way up the spine to the neck. During each segment, instructor Edya Kalev explains what to do and how it should feel. There were no crazy-hard poses, but getting rolled is challenging in itself when you sit tensely at a desk for ten hours every day. While nothing was particularly strenuous—and the slow pace helped me keep up with more experienced MELTers—at the end of class I was exhausted, as though I’d had a major workout. A few hours later, after rehydrating and eating something, I was loose-limbed and centered.—Lucy Quintanilla
Level: Yoga newbies welcome
Schedule varies, please check website for details.

version.name: Amrit Yoga
version.description: This style of practice aims to make Eastern philosophies more accessible to the Western way of life. Beginners to Amrit or yoga are welcome.

version.name: Going Steady
version.description: Zachary Sims, Alex Grubard and Zach Broussard host a bunch of stand-ups at this new weekly Williamsburg show.

version.name: Midnight Music
version.description: Pianist-singer Erik James anchors this open-mike night.

version.name: Mostly Sondheim
version.description: A lazy Susan of hosts (including Ben Cameron and the iron-lunged Kate Pazakis) spin in and out of this lively open-mike show-tune night, joined by Garrit Guadan at the piano.

event.name: Iyengar Yoga Level 1 with Matt Dreyfus

version.name: Iyengar Yoga Level 1 with Matt Dreyfus
version.description:
Dreyfus demonstrates almost every posture on a small stage, and goes around the room to correct students’ postures. The class proceeds at a slow pace, with frequent demonstrations and meticulous attention to the body’s alignment. This is a great class for those who are new to Iyengar yoga, a practice based on the teachings of the 91-year-old yoga master B.K.S. Iyengar, author of the classic yoga treatise Light on Yoga. The airy, modern studio has large changing rooms and provides all necessary equipment. The class (and Iyengar Yoga in general) incorporates a lot of props —more advanced Iyengar classes may even involve suspension from ropes. You’ll be challenged but not exhausted in this beginners’ class—don’t expect a vigorous workout, but your heart rate will rise as you hold and adjust the poses per the instructor’s detailed directions. Dreyfus is patient, attentive, methodical and true to B.K.S. Iyengar’s classic teachings and techniques—no surprise there: He has studied with the master himself in India.—Shayna D. Skarf
Level: Yoga newbies can do it.
Schedule varies, please check website for details.

version.name: “South African Photographs: David Goldblatt”
version.description: The great artist’s lens capture apartheid. Through Sept 19.

version.name: “In Passing”
version.description: In honor of Women’s History Month, the library presents this exhibit of three female photographers who passed away in 2009. The featured photographers are German-born Evelyn Hofer, New York street photographer Helen Levitt and former SVA teacher Lilo Raymond.

version.name: Program library
version.description: This pop-culture nirvana contains an archive of more than 100,000 radio and TV programs. Just head to the fourth-floor library and search the database for your favorite episode of I Love Lucy, Seinfeld or Desperate Housewives, then tune in (and veg out) at your assigned console.

version.name: The Statue of Liberty
version.property: Lady Liberty—or Liberty Enlightening the World, as she’s officially known—was a gift from France on America’s 100th birthday. A universal symbol of freedom, the copper-plated sentinel stands 305 feet tall from the bottom of her base to the tip of her torch. Reservations are required for a tour of the statue’s interior.

version.name: Spinning at the Studio
version.description: I worked so hard in this class, I still felt wiped out four hours later. Or was that the feeling of fat cells being gobbled up by my raised metabolism? I hope so, because without physical benefits, I don’t know why anybody would put themselves through a Spinning class. The upbeat, driving music was perfectly coordinated with our sprints and recovery, and the instructor spouted motivational mantras throughout class, all of which kept me going way beyond what I would have thought I was capable of. But I’ll be happy if I never hear “stay with it, stay with it—riiide that hill” again. How fit you need to be: Gym regular.—Megan Gendell

version.name: “Getting By: Immigrants Weathering Hard Times”
version.description: Hour-long tours of the German Jewish Gumpertz (1870s) and Sicilian Catholic Baldizzi (1930s) family apartments reveal the imaginative means that these real-life enclaves employed to overcome hard times and forge new lives in America. Tours run every 30 minutes.

version.name: “Immigrant Soles”
version.description: This walking tour, which takes participants around the area immediately surrounding the Tenement Museum, focuses on the everyday lives of immigrants who lived on the Lower East Side in the early 20th century.

event.name: “Piecing It Together: Immigrants in the Garment Industry”

version.name: “Piecing It Together: Immigrants in the Garment Industry”
version.description: This hour-long tour visits the re-created 1897 apartment–garment shop run by the Polish Levine family and the 1918 apartment of the Rogarshevsky family, who are mourning the loss of their patriarch, Abraham. Along the way, you’ll hear about the lives of European, Asian and Latino immigrants who worked in the garment industry. Tours run every 30 minutes.

version.name: “The Moores—An Irish Family in America”
version.description: This hour-long tour explores the working-class Irish immigrant experience through the story of a family coping with the death of a child in 1869.

version.name: “The Confino Family Apartment”
version.description: The museum presents a tour of a Sephardic Jewish family’s apartment.

version.name: “Getting By: Past and Present”
version.description: The museum’s newest program invites visitors to participate in tours rather than just experience them. As patrons go through the museum, they are encouraged to share their thoughts on issues and historic events that they are learning about (including immigration and class conflict).

event.name: Love, Linda: the Life of Mrs. Cole Porter

version.name: Love, Linda: the Life of Mrs. Cole Porter
version.vendor-category: Gay & Lesbian | It's Here, It's Queer
version.description: Jazz-cabaret singer Stevie Holland plays the gay Broadway composer Cole Porter’s wife, Linda, in a beard-stroking tribute to an unusual marriage arrangement (illustrated with Porter’s witty songs).

version.name: Stevie Holland: Love, Linda
version.description: Jazz-cabaret singer Stevie Holland plays gay Broadway composer Cole Porter’s wife, Linda, in a beard-stroking tribute to an unusual marriage arrangement (illustrated with Porter’s witty songs).

version.name: Love, Linda
version.description: Jazz-cabaret singer Stevie Holland plays the gay Broadway composer Cole Porter’s wife, Linda, in a beard-stroking tribute to an unusual marriage arrangement (illustrated with Porter’s witty songs).

version.name: The United Nations Headquarters
version.price: $12.50, seniors and students $8, children 5–14 $6.50, children under 5 not admitted

version.name: Vinyasa Restorative
version.description:
The class opens with some words on gratitude and the standard three-om chant. It’s followed by a fairly vigorous hour of sun salutations and standing poses, plus stretching, strengthening and reclining restorative postures, some of which we held for 10 to 15 minutes. In the spacious new Astoria location, instructor Anya circulated throughout the class, assisting with correct alignment and posture-deepening during the vinyasa sequence, and helping students set up bolsters, blocks and blankets for the restorative portion of the class. She also offered each of us a neck massage using lavender oil (I accepted, gratefully). I occasionally had trouble keeping up, possibly because I hadn’t been to a class in about a year. The vinyasa sequence was an invigorating, heart-rate-raising workout, and the restorative portion meant that the session’s overall effect was just that.—Carolyn Juris
Level: Some experience helps.
Schedule varies, please check website for details.

version.name: Three Treasures Acupuncture’s special
version.description: According to facial acupuncturist Mindy Pickard, cold weather can cause your facial muscles to contract. Add to that dry radiator heat and killer winds, and it’s a bad season for your visage. Facial-rejuvenation acupuncture can both alleviate dryness and stimulate those shocked muscles by bringing blood back into the right areas. Pickard and her needles can also target wrinkles, jowls or skin sags.

version.name: Transcendental Meditation technique
version.description: Since Maharishi Mahesh Yogi introduced this practice to the U.S. 50 years ago, more than 37,000 New Yorkers have adopted it. Learn about its benefits to the mind and body at these free introductory lectures. Reservations required.

version.name: Triangulo
version.description: Argentine tango: •Advanced-beginner technique: Wed 7:30–8:30pm, Thu 6:30–7:30pm. •Beginner: Tue, Thu 7:30–8:30pm. •Intermediate: Tue 8:30–9:30pm. •Intermediate-advanced: Thu 8:30–9:30pm. •Preintermediate: Wed 8:30–9:30pm.

event.name: Union Square: Crossroads of New York

version.name: Union Square: Crossroads of New York
version.description: In 1861, Union Square was the site of a massive pro–Union Army rally, the biggest public assembly America had seen at that time. Twenty-one years later, it was the backdrop for the first Labor Day celebration. Today, you can stand in the aisles at Forever 21 and try on a shirtdress over your jeans. Learn about the park’s evolving history as a New York landmark on this free 90-minute tour.

event.name: Jack Jeffers and the New York Classics

version.name: Jack Jeffers and the New York Classics
version.description: Tuba player and bass-trombonist Jack Jeffers doesn’t call his 16-piece collective the New York Classics for nothing; you’ll have no trouble recognizing pieces such as Ellington’s “Mood Indigo,” Mingus’s “Goodbye, Pork Pie Hat” and Jobim’s “Corcovado.” He’s been in solidarity with avant-polymaths like drummer Warren Smith and Rahsaan Roland Kirk’s pianist Sonelius Smith for more than three decades, which explains why Jeffers’s soloists tend to come at both the familiar tunes and his originals from an inventively off-kilter base.

event.name: Sugar Hill Jazz Quartet with Patience Higgins

version.name: Sugar Hill Jazz Quartet with Patience Higgins
version.description: See Mon 21.

version.name: Vanguard Jazz Orchestra
version.description: Monday night big bands are now a hometown staple, but this is the one that started it all. Rolling past 40 years in this slot, the orchestra created by late greats Thad Jones and Mel Lewis lives on.

version.name: Anusara
version.description:
Elena Brower, Virayoga co-owner and yoga celeb, leads a challenging class, giving personal adjustments in the packed room of 60-plus students without interrupting the flow—or her ongoing discourse about inner spiritual symmetry and peace. I recoiled a little when I entered the studio 20 minutes before class to find mats already crammed nose to nose across the floor. And when I noticed $3 drink-mix packets for sale at the front desk (nutritional support for pre- and postyoga bliss). And when the teacher walked in wearing skinny jeans and an expensive haircut. She sat down, dumped some drink mix into a water bottle—and taught a stunning class. She methodically and thoughtfully guided our movement, our alignment and our attention in each pose. Well-sequenced flows opened up my lungs, focused my mind and unknotted my lower back. I loved poses I thought I hated. I learned new approaches to poses I’ve done for years. I never once bumped into my neighbors six inches away.—Megan Gendell
Level: Serious yogis only.
Schedule varies, please check website for details.

version.name: Chamber Magic
version.description: Steve Cohen, a.k.a. the Millionaires’ Magician, conjures up an intimate evening of parlor magic at the Waldorf-Astoria.

event.name: Love, Loss, and What I Wore

version.name: Love, Loss, and What I Wore
version.description: The central point of Nora and Delia Ephron’s well-judged, sweetly enjoyable monologue-athon (inspired by Ilene Beckerman’s illustrated memoir) is not that clothes make the woman; it’s that clothes make the woman talk. If wardrobe reveals our existential confusion, the Ephron sisters know exactly who we are. The ensemble currently includes Lucy DeVito, Judy Gold, Melissa Joan Hart, Shirley Knight and Capathia Jenkins.—HS

version.name: Level II Vinyasa
version.description:
Don’t look for any downtime in this fast-paced class; poses change rapidly, but not so quickly that you’ll feel rushed. I received a hug immediately upon entering the studio, so I knew I was in for a much more holistic experience than the intimidating classes I had taken before. Instructor and co-owner Liz Buehler Walker was extremely encouraging throughout the session (despite my lack of coordination and flexibility), guiding my awkward limbs into position without disturbing my Zen. By the end of the class I felt both exhausted (I sweated way more than I had at any other traditional yoga class) and invigorated with peaceful energy.—Christy Purington
Level: Some experience helps.
Schedule varies, please check website for details.

version.name: Basics II
version.description:
Sun salutations and basic yoga poses (downward-facing dog, warriors one and two, bridge, etc.) are interspersed with more difficult work, like inversions (poses that lift the feet above the head). The class begins with chanting and prayers in Sanskrit. This class is challenging without being overwhelming, especially for a yoga beginner: You’re constantly moving, with few moments of rest in between poses (and the room is quite balmy thanks to a space heater and closed windows—expect to sweat). Happily, instructor Katelin is the type who will move your arms into the correct position, or have you grab her ankles to properly execute a pose. That sort of hands-on instruction makes it easier to stay motivated.—Amy Plitt
Level: Some experience helps.

version.name: Vinyasa - Beginner and Intermediate
version.description:
Flowing poses, including standing poses, balances, forward and back bends, twists and basic inversions. A little chanting, and basic principles of yoga are taught. This class could be dubbed “motivational yoga.” Our teacher was delightfully enthusiastic about the peace ’n’ love principles behind yoga, and the tone of the lesson was empowering (“Yeah! That’s beautiful!”). Poses are satisfyingly challenging, but still fine for a first-timer (at the end of the class, instructor David led us in applause for tonight’s yoga virgin). Located squarely in midtown hell, Yogasutra is an intimate haven for frantic New Yorkers.—Sophie Harris
Level: Yoga newbies can do it.
Schedule varies, please check website for details.

version.name: Power Vinyasa Yoga
version.description:
Quick movement through poses, followed by ten minutes of slower relaxation poses. You’ll work up a sweat—and not just because you’re packed tightly among the other yoga freeloaders who frequent this by-donation spot. While some may mind being mere inches from their neighbors, the dense crowd guarantees anonymity, making this class perfect for self-conscious beginners. A rotating cast of teachers guides you through a standard vinyasa sequence to the soundtrack of their indie-ish playlists. There are enough challenges for more experienced yogis to stretch their capacity too.—Kate Lowenstein
Level: Yoga newbies can do it.
Schedule varies, please check website for details.

version.name: Ditch Comedy Sundays
version.description: Yannis Pappas hosts a different lineup of local comics each week and screens shorts from Ditch Films.

version.name: Betsey Johnson
version.description: In step with this exuberant, cartwheeling designer, who once employed Edie Sedgwick as her shop's model, the superfemme party dresses at this boutique exude a hip, retro vibe. Leopard-print everything, lacey lingerie and '50s-style pin-up glamour attract savvy teens looking for prom outfits and grown-up lasses seeking adorable, young-at-heart pieces.

version.name: Etsy
version.description: DIYers flock to this Web company—the eBay of all things handmade. Fittingly, its 7,000-square-foot warehouse won't disappoint crafty types (and wanna-bes), offering free classes in everything from sewing and knitting to soap making.

version.name: Vinyasa-Basic
version.description:
Poses are linked in a flowing vinyasa style, but you go slowly in this basics class. Includes standing poses, balances, forward and back bends, twists and basic inversions, plus teaching of “mindfulness.”There’s no luxury-gift-boutique nonsense at Greenhouse’s three Williamsburg studios—just great, inspiring yoga practice. The spaces are light and welcoming, and the teachers helpful and sweet, assisting with poses as necessary. There’s a bit of chanting in the basics classes, and your instructor might talk a little about the principles of yoga—but by the end, you’ll feel beautifully worked out. Background music is subtle and restful; students tend to be young and hot.—Sophie Harris
Level: Yoga newbies can do it.

version.name: Trike
version.description: Nick Kanellis and Peter McNerney, two of the guys from Statues of Liberty, add a new element (Leslie Korein) to form their improv trio, Trike.

version.name: Magnet Inferno
version.description: Two improv teams receive a challenge before each show—something they must incorporate into scenes, or an impediment of some kind. Whichever is deemed the winner returns the following week to fight again.

version.name: The Deconstruction + Sleep Over!
version.description: A combination of the theater’s top-brass improvisers bring fast-paced and hilarious play to two long-form formats; one form breaks down an audience suggestion into lots of short scenes and the other slowly meshes characters’ disparate worlds until they’re all on stage together.

version.name: Thursday Night Out
version.description: The Big Stage Blackout is at 8pm, when all-stars drop by to play (in the slot currently: the Deconstruction). At 9 and 10pm, veteran house teams play. Come early for the mixer at 7pm, in which anyone can perform. Five bones covers the whole evening and PBRs are only $1.

version.name: Megawatt
version.description: A rotating crew of house teams, curated by theater director Armando Diaz, improvises a variety of long-forms.

version.name: The Made-Up Musical
version.description: John O’Donnell and a rotating cast of singing improvisers create full musicals on the spot, with Frank Spitznagel on the piano.

version.name: Lead McEnroe + Taco Supreme
version.description: First Mike Barry, Nick Benaquista, Tim Eberle, Dan Scivoletti and Rob Williams perform a long-form improv set inspired by a location that means something to an audience member. Then Brigid Boyle, Elizabeth Findlay, Alexis Saarela and Ashley Ward fancy up their street treats with another 30 minute improv set.

version.name: 4Track
version.description: Four of the Magnet’s top improvisers spin one word into four big scenes featuring characters whose worlds eventually collide.

version.name: “Untitled.”
version.description: The inaugural show of this new Sunset Park space, which will serve as an accumulative museum, features a single piece by sound artist Andy Graydon. Ongoing.

event.name: Fort Greene, Clinton Hill and Brooklyn Heights

version.name: Fort Greene, Clinton Hill and Brooklyn Heights
version.description: Mauricio Lorence leads a three-hour excursion through some of the borough’s oldest and most charming neighborhoods, with a focus on historic sites, ethnic enclaves and municipal institutions.

version.name: The Art of Strength
version.description:
What to expect: A circuit of strength-based exercises using kettlebells, ropes and logs. Twenty-second microsets are followed by one-minute rest periods.
Before this workout, I’d never lifted a kettlebell (picture a cannonball with a handle, ranging from 8 to 32 kilos), so I didn’t know what to expect. Surprisingly, the unusual weight proved versatile: We used them in everything from dead lifts to through-the-legs-and-round-the-back figure eights. Additional exercises with ropes, logs and a medicine ball on a leash (menacingly dubbed the “tornado ball”) kept the workout both interesting and challenging. There’s definitely a community of seasoned regulars here, and the quick pace results in a steep learning curve for newbies. You’ll be panting by the third station, but the abbreviated sets encourage a full-throttle approach.—Dan Lopez
How in shape you need to be: Gym regular

version.name: The Lion King
version.description: Director-designer wizard Julie Taymor surrounds the Disney movie’s mythic plot and Elton John–Tim Rice score with African rhythm and music. Through elegant puppetry, Taymor populates the stage with a menagerie of African beasts; her staging has expanded a simple cub into the pride of Broadway.—AF

event.name: “Timescapes: A Multimedia Portrait of New York”

version.name: “Timescapes: A Multimedia Portrait of New York”
version.description: This 25-minute multimedia program, narrated by Stanley Tucci, traces the growth of New York through animated maps, archival photos and paintings from the museum’s collections.

version.name: “Perform”
version.description: Photos, props and costumes—including Mrs. Potts’s outfit from the Broadway run of Walt Disney’s Beauty and the Beast (a spectacular lace-and-bead creation that was initially too large to fit through the theater door)—reveal the storied history of the New York stage.

version.name: Mary Poppins
version.description: Here’s a new beast for Disney’s musical menagerie: a tuner that adults can enjoy. Based on the 1964 movie and P.L. Travers’s original, darker novel, the story tells of overworked parents who hire an odd nanny (Laura Michelle Kelly) to tame their horrid brats. Director Richard Eyre and book writer Julian Fellowes sneak a spoonful of medicine into the copious amounts of sugar.—DC

version.name: Jets Flight Crew Workout
version.description: The experience: This low-impact dance class—a limited-engagement workout only offered during Jets season—was a welcome break for my sore muscles, which got the serious stretching they needed. Two members of the Jets Flight Crew (the team’s official cheerleading dance squad) practically coddled us through a short, energetic routine, slowly going over each step, inviting questions and encouraging frequent water breaks. I certainly couldn’t pop it like the ladies in the front of the room, but mastering the moves wasn’t the goal so much as was having fun. By the end of the class, having barely perspired, I could relate to the Flight Crew on one level: Cheerleaders don’t sweat; they glisten. How fit you need to be: Couch potatoes welcome.—Cristina Velocci
version.price: Free and open to the public

version.name: Kundalini Yoga
version.description:
Class opens and closes with a series of chants; we were concentrating on the “positive mind” aspect of Kundalini thought. Physically, the sequences are not very strenuous. The kindly teacher was a pro at creating an environment conducive to positive thinking. She lit incense, turned on music, and explained and encouraged us the whole way through a precisely timed sequence of two-minute postures, followed by familiar exercises (like leg lifts and jogging in place), and finishing with meditation. Throughout the class we practiced “Breath of Fire,” a technique meant to open up your lungs and allow your body to melt into that elusive positive energy.—Jessica Rohls
Level: Yoga newbies welcome.
Schedule varies, please check website for details.

version.name: Trina Turk
version.description: This Left Coast designer collaborated with chipper home-design star Jonathan Adler on her first NYC outpost. The resulting 2,500-square-foot space evokes 1970s Big Sur style with white terra-cotta tiles, chairs styled after coral and a giant wooden tree sculpture. The decor provides a fitting backdrop for Turk’s vibrantly hued, vintage-inspired garb for ladies. A small collection of menswear, which features an assortment of supersoft cashmere sweaters, ensures that the Y-chromosome set won’t be left out in the cold.

version.name: Yoga I and II
version.description:
Low on chants and grunts, high on individual attention and poses held for a minute or less. Married couple Danny Kim and Helen Sim opened this yoga–tai chi studio back in 2007, seeing a need for spiritually informed workouts in the area. The ten-person class (nine women and this reporter) gathered in a clean, spacious studio to sweat out an easy series while Sim attended to our every move. A final 15 minutes of meditation is enough to reinvigorate you for the journey home.—David Yi
Level: Yoga newbies can do it.

version.name: Complimentary Yoga Classes
version.description: You have no excuse to not to work out now that the Williamsburg Beacon Center is offering gratis yoga sessions. Geared toward beginners, the lessons will cover breathing, meditation and different postures. No moolah is required—just bring your own towel or mat.

version.name: “Otto Dix”
version.description: This exhibition of the German painter and printmaker is the first show in the United States devoted exclusively to the Expressionist’s oeuvre. Through Aug 30.

version.name: The Luxury Chocolate Tour
version.description: The cultural institutions along Fifth Avenue’s Museum Mile are a magnificent feast for the eyes. But Chocolate ZOOM’s tour of Upper East Side chocolatiers—including Debauve & Gallais and La Maison du Chocolat—is designed to give your taste buds a thrill. A warning, though: After sampling cocoa-infused delicacies like Grand Marnier truffles, violet-infused chocolate squares and raspberry bonbons, you’ll never go back to Hershey’s.

version.name: Stage Door Tour
version.description: Stroll through Radio City’s gorgeous Art Deco interior, learn the secrets of the Great Stage and its intricate hydraulics system, and meet one of the high-kicking Radio City Rockettes on this popular behind-the-scenes tour.

version.name: Nutrition Town Hall
version.description: Whoever said there’s strength in numbers would agree that it’s a good idea to attend this weekly nutrition support and educational meeting. Led by certified nutritionist Robert Crayhon, the gathering will help foster a sense of community where everyone helps each other to achieve optimal wellness. It also aims to help you prevent and manage a wide range of health conditions. People of all religious and cultural backgrounds as well as those with any specific dietary restrictions or disabilities are welcome to attend.

version.name: Pilates Mandi
version.description: The experience: Instructor Mandi Neubecker led us through step-aerobics-type choreography on mini trampolines, set to a bouncy alternative-rock soundtrack, with interludes on the ground for Pilates-based body sculpting and ab work. I exerted the most effort trying to keep up with the jumps, jogs and kicks on the trampoline, which were all super fast, in time with the music and usually with coordinating arm movements. The footwork took all my concentration—and I’m a dancer. But most of the students bounced only a rough approximation of Neubecker’s moves, and that seemed good enough; she didn’t criticize or correct anybody, and we all kept our bodies moving for an hour. It was fun to train my brain-to-legs connection, while the workout for my heart and lungs passed almost under my radar. How fit you need to be: Gym regular.—Megan Gendell

version.name: Mamma Mia!
version.description: Almost two dozen hits from the ’70s pop sensation ABBA form the spine of this worldwide smash, which book writer Catherine Johnson has feebly fleshed out into a mother-daughter comedy-drama. As theater, Mamma Mia! is forgettable. As a delivery system for pop-culture nostalgia, it’s ruthless.—DC

version.name: LAFCO Warehouse Store
version.description: Weekly happenings are the best: New episodes of Gossip Girl, new issues of TONY and the weekly markdown fest at your new favorite store. Stop by for chichi soaps, lotions, candles and body-care products—all up to 75% off. This Italian beauty company is offering up a variety of sweet-smelling goods, with nothing amounting to more than $40. Lorenzo Villoresi room sprays are chopped from $45 to $8 and Claus Porto vanilla-scented soy-blend candles are $13 (were $32) and floral-blended soaps are $3 (normally $7). TGIF!

version.name: New York Botanical Garden
version.price: $6, seniors $3, students $2, children 2–12 $1, children under 2 free. Combination admission (includes Everett Children’s Adventure Garden): $18, seniors and students $16, children 2–12 $5, children under 2 free
version.property: Among the diverse specimens found in this urban Eden are banana trees, moth orchids, the largest collection of New World palms in captivity and a 50-acre tract of pristine forest. Fri 30–June 13: “Emily Dickinson's Garden: The Poetry of Flowers” Various flora, including herbs and wildflowers, enlivened Emily Dickinson’s work; to show how nature inspired the reclusive poet, the garden has created different flowering displays that link wildlife and her writing, including a replication of her family’s propety in Amherst, Massachussetts. Plus, you’ll be able to see artifacts, including original manuscripts of Dickinson’s work, that shed more light on her life.

version.name: Rockbear Beer Blasts
version.description: Joe Fiore (Dance 208) hosts this furry evening of libations.

version.name: American Idiot
version.description: Whether you’re a Broadway nostalgist longing for trad song and dance, or a sullen teen who vicariously thrills to the cast’s grimacing, bird-flipping punks, this Green Day–scored rock musical should satisfy. For the time that American Idiot has you in its white-knuckle grasp, it will electrify and overwhelm your senses. Michael Mayer pulls out all the directorial stops in this orgy of floor-pounding dance, video washes, concert lighting and constant movement. Suburban anomie, urban ennui and wartime tragedy—American Idiot is Hair’s sullen, cynical grandchild.—DC

version.name: Feldenkrais Awareness Through Movement
version.description: This method uses gentle exercises and directed attention to improve range of motion, increase flexibility and restore our innate capacity for efficient movement. In this class, you’ll be guided through a sequence of simple positions and encouraged to focus on them in a way that raises physical self-awareness.

version.name: Money Wheel
version.description: Gusty Winds is the wheel-spinnin’ hostess at this weekly party with the $500 jackpot. Go-go dancers take over at 1am.

version.name: Warrior Fitness Boot Camp
version.description:
What to expect: The workout starts with brief stretching, and then moves into a variety of strengthening activities and calisthenics, including lunging, crunching, climbing and an obstacle course.
My regular exercise routine consists of a Spin class and some free weights, but that’s child’s play compared with this boot camp. It was intense, and I was sweating from the get-go, but the drill instructors were both firm and encouraging, which really motivated me to get through the hour. I thought I was faring pretty well during all the jumping jacks, crunches and even the obstacle course—but then I came to the stairs. Running up and down 12 flights after hoisting myself over walls and swinging from monkey bars was enough to drive a girl to the brink; I had to hang my head out a window to keep from tossing the humus I ate a couple of hours earlier. But when it looked as though I was losing steam, the other participants offered their support, cheering, “You can do it, you’re almost there!” and “You’re doing great!” Their votes of confidence kept my energy up. This class was definitely one of the most challenging regimes I’ve ever put myself through, but I would do it all over again. Just next time, I’d do it without the hummus.—Shaina Park
How in shape you need to be: Gym regular

version.name: Daily meditation
version.description: It’s said that this peaceful practice enables us to create new attitudes and responses to life, attain a deeper understanding of ourselves, and rediscover and use our positive qualities. And, hey, it’s free, you can’t get worked up about that!

event.name: Hump Night of the Iguana with Richard Skipper

version.name: Hump Night of the Iguana with Richard Skipper
version.description: Richard Skipper, best known for channeling Carol Channing carols, hosts this weekly cabaret variety show.

Best to leave the young’uns at home if you attend this scatological circus of cruelty, which may be the only Spanish bouffon spectacle targeting the pro–death-penalty crowd. Playing death-row inmates, the show’s accomplished quartet of Madrid-based clowns enact wordless vignettes, in which just about every bodily fluid is simulated and flung. It’s a sick treat that can only be called commedia dell’farte.—DC

version.name: Promises, Promises
version.description: Sean Hayes (Will & Grace) and Kristin Chenoweth (Wicked) headline a revival of this swinging 1968 musical with music by Burt Bacharach, lyrics by Hal David and book by Neil Simon. Based on Billy Wilder’s The Apartment, the story concerns an upwardly mobile junior executive, the waitress he loves and his bachelor pad—a handy locale for trysts.

version.name: Buddies
version.description: Join DJ Damian at this weekly bear soiree.

version.name: Ilori
version.description: Organized like a gallery, this luxe eyewear boutique displays more than 1,400 styles of sunglasses in small, brightly lit cubes for easy access. If you’re stumped about which shades to pick, a wall in the front showcases a rotating staff-curated selection, and the knowledgeable employees will help you figure out which shields best fit your face’s shape. Trendsetters will gravitate toward emerging lines such as Derek Lam, Chloé and John Varvatos, as well as a variety of exclusive and limited-edition pieces; traditionalists can opt for frames from classic companies like Ray-Ban and Persol.

version.name: La Cage aux Folles
version.description: It’s only been six years since the last revival of the Harvey Fierstein–Jerry Herman musical comedy, but who’s counting? This production from England’s Menier Chocolate Factory comes to Broadway after a popular run on the West End. Kelsey Grammer and Douglas Hodge headline Terry Johnson’s production as club owner Georges and his temperamental drag-queen lover, Albin.

version.name: Enron
version.description: Direct from the West End, director Rupert Goold and writer Lucy Prebble revisit the massive Enron financial scandal, in an ambitious piece that incorporates video, dance and docudrama. The cast includes Norbert Leo Butz as CEO Jeffrey Skilling, as well as Marin Mazzie. Apparently, history occurs first as tragedy and recurs as multimedia spectacle.

version.name: Not Friday!
version.description: Adam Pateman, James Harris and John Szeluga bring a weekly stand-up show to the old Mo’ Pitkins space.

version.name: Breath Made Visible
version.description: Ruedi Gerber’s documentary explores the life of legendary dance pioneer Anna Halprin.

version.name: Behind the Burly Q
version.description: This film, directed by Leslie Zemeckis, explores the history of burlesque; subjects interviewed include Alan Alda (whose father was a “tit singer”), journalist Nat Bodian, and dancers Lorraine Lee and Tempest Storm.

version.name: Thursday’s the New Friday
version.description: Del Harrison hosts this biweekly showcase featuring fellow stand-ups. Wine lovers, take note: A free glass of wine comes with every dinner purchase.
